properties.name: Assyria (kingdom)
properties.description: Au0161u0161ur, later Mu0101t Au0161u0161ur ('the land of the god Au0161u0161ur'), grew from a small city-state and important trading center to a powerful, wide-spread empire. At is zenith in the seventh century BC, the Assyrian Empire (883-609 BC) dominated much of the Middle East and the Eastern Mediterranean, stretching from the Persian Gulf in the south to the Mediterranean Sea in the west. Assyria's heartland, an area also referred to as Subartu, roughly corresponds to northern Iraq (Nineveh Governorate) and includes the numerous important cities, especially Au0161u0161ur (Assyria's traditional religious and administrative capital), Kalhu, Dur-u0160arrukin, and Nineveh (the capital of the Assyrian Empire).

properties.name: Bam

properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 31 D4 Ad Portum?

properties.name: Am(p)saga (river)
properties.description: A river of north Africa, a portion of which formed the boundary between Mauretania and Numidia.

properties.name: Assarath? (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 31 D3 Assarath? fl.

properties.name: Azimacia
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 31 F4 Azimacia

properties.name: Caput Amsagae
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 31 F4 Caput Amsagae

properties.name: Castellum Gurolense
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 31 C4 Castellum Gurolense

properties.name: Chitouai
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 31 E3 Chitouai

properties.name: Cirta/Constantina
properties.description: The capital city of the ancient Berber Kingdom of Numidia.

properties.name: Sarvestan Palace
properties.description: The Sassanid Palace at Sarvestan is an elite building of the fifth century A.D. It is located approximately 90 km southeast of Shiraz.

properties.name: Investiture relief of Ardashir I
properties.description: A rock-cut relief depicting the investiture of Ardashir I, ca. A.D. 226-242. This relief is the earliest Sasanian monument at Naqu0161-e Rustam.

properties.name: Hijovejo
properties.description: A fortified, pre-Roman oppidum with concentric fortification circuits, the site of Hijovejo existed during a transitional phase in Iberia (second century B.C. to first century A.D.)

properties.name: Sun Temple of Niuserre
properties.description: Temple dedicated to the god Ra in the 5th dynasty by the pharaoh Niuserre (Nyuserre).

properties.name: Bagras Castle
properties.description: Bagras Castle is located in Turkey's u0130skenderun district in the Amanus Mountains. The tenth-century castle was rebuilt in the twelfth century.

properties.name: Anduarsalia
properties.description: A fortress in the vicinity of Til-garimmu fortified by the Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721-705 BC) against Uraru1e6du.

properties.name: Luhsu
properties.description: A fortress in the vicinity of Til-garimmu fortified by the Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721-705 BC) against Uraru1e6du.

properties.name: Carnac megaliths
properties.description: Carnac (Breton: Karnag) is a site in southern Brittany known for the so-called Carnac stones, a massive complex of Neolithic menhir stones.

properties.name: Tuscan Archipelago
properties.description: A chain of islands between the Ligurian Sea and Tyrrhenian Sea.

properties.name: Pecile at Hadrian's Villa
properties.description: An artificial terrace surrounding a large pond, 30 m wide x 116 m long, located at the western end of Villa Adriana.

properties.name: Sepulcrum Hirtii
properties.description: The tomb of Aulus Hirtius, consul in 43 B.C., was discovered beneath the northwest corner of the Palazzo della Cancelleria in Rome in 1938.

properties.name: Castellammare della Bruca
properties.description: A fortified medieval settlement that succeeds the acropolis of ancient Velia.

properties.name: Casale Ciuffa
properties.description: The Casale Ciuffa occupied the site of a Roman villa; this site now lies within the footprint of the Parco degli Ulivi in the modern comune of Colonna, Lazio.

properties.name: u00c7atalhu00f6yu00fck
properties.description: A Neolithic and Chalcolithic settlement of southern Anatolia, inabited ca. 7500 B.C. to 5700 B.C. In July 2012, it was inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

properties.name: Tower of the Winds
properties.description: Also known as the Horologion of Andronikos Kyrrhestes, the Tower of the Winds is an octagonal Pentelic marble clocktower located in the Roman Agora that functioned as a horologion.

properties.name: Theatrum Marcelli
properties.description: Theatrum Marcelli (Theater of Marcellus) is an ancient Roman theater in the Circus Flaminius. Augustus completed its construction and dedicated it in 12 BC.

properties.name: Santi Giovanni e Paolo
properties.description: An ancient Christian basilica on the Caelian Hill in Rome that was built in AD 398 by will of a senator known as Pammachius. The basilica was located over the home of two Roman soldiers, John and Paul, who had been martyred under Julian in AD 362. The church was thus called the Titulus Pammachii.

properties.name: Mont'e Prama
properties.description: A locality near Cabras, Sardinia, where, in 1974, the cache of monumental prehistoric stone sculptures known as the Giants of Mont'e Prama was discovered.

properties.name: Kirkbride
properties.description: A Roman fort at Bowness on Solway on the Stanegate.

properties.name: Piazza d'Oro at Hadrian's Villa
properties.description: One of the largest and most luxurious complexes of Villa Hadriani. It is situated at the northern end of the Villa, and consists of a vast building, with a vaulted, octagonal vestibule to the north, a cenatio to the south, and a central quadriporticus, down the middle of which runs a canal.

properties.name: Garden and Pool Complex at Petra
properties.description: Garden terrace and monumental pool with island pavilion dates to the Nabataean/Early Roman periods, 9 BCE-c. 200 CE. Formerly called the Lower Market.

properties.name: Mausoleum of Clesippus Geganius
properties.description: The ruins of a first century B.C. Roman tomb along the Via Appia at Mesa di Pontinia.

properties.name: Tel Yokneam
properties.description: Settlement in northern Palestine inhabited from the Early Bronze Age through the Mamluk period.

properties.name: Via Olevano Romano columbarium
properties.description: A late republican to early imperial columbarium along the Via Praenestina. The columbarium is of rectangular plan and was last used during the early Flavian period.

properties.name: Mausoleo della Conocchia
properties.description: A Roman mausoleum dating most likely to the second century.

properties.name: Tigris Tunnel Inscriptions
properties.description: The so-called Tigris Tunnel is a cave ca. fifty miles north of Diyarbaku0131r, Turkey and it forms a source of the Tigris River. In its vicinity there are several Assyrian monuments, including five inscriptions.

properties.name: Temple of Castor and Pollux, Cora
properties.description: The Temple of Castor and Pollux at Cora was originally built between the fourth and the second centuries B.C. The partially extant architrave carries an inscription of the first century B.C.

properties.description: The pyramid tombs of the kings of the Kushite kingdom.

properties.name: Aymont
properties.description: A Spanish village that borders Portugal and is located in the southwest of the province of Huenca. Known as Ayamonte today, it once belonged to the kingdom of Alfonso X.

properties.name: Arch of Marcus Aurelius at Tripoli
properties.description: A quadrifons arch at ancient Oea (modern Tripoli) that commemorates Roman victories over the Parthians in A.D. 161.

properties.description: Chaldaici? L. was an extensive marshland near the junction of the Euphrates and Tigris rivers.

properties.name: E-kara/Icarus (island)
properties.description: Failaka Island in the Persian Gulf.

properties.name: Elam
properties.description: An ancient Pre-Iranian civilization located in the west and southwest of modern-day Iran.

properties.name: Elymais/Susiana
properties.description: Susiana, derived from the city of Susa, is the Classical appellation for Elam.

properties.name: Euphrates (river)
properties.description: The longest river of Western Asia, the Euphrates flows from the Kara Su and the Murat Su to the confluence with the Tigris river.

properties.name: Khabiu1e63
properties.description: Neolithic site located about 5 km east of the town of Shadad on the edge of the Dasht-i Lut (Lut desert) in southeastern Iran.

properties.name: Theater of Pyrrhus
properties.description: The Hellenistic theater at Dodona is linked to the reign of Pyrrhus in the third century B.C.

properties.name: Forum Iulium
properties.description: The Forum Iulium (or Forum of Caesar, Forum Caesaris) is a forum built by Iulius Caesar and dedicated ca. 46 B.C. The main cult of the forum is that of Venus Genetrix.

properties.name: Roman villa at Verige Bay
properties.description: A Roman villa rustica located in the bay of Verige, dating from the first century B.C. through the sixth century A.D. The villa's ruins lie within Croatia's Brijuni National Park.

properties.name: Provadiiu0361a-Solnitu0361sata
properties.description: A Neolithic and Chalcolithic tell that was a site of salt-processing in eastern Bulgaria.

properties.name: Guldara Stupa
properties.description: Buddhist monastery and stupa site in Afghanistan's Guldara Valley, dated to the Kushan period (2nd century CE).

properties.name: Torre Caetani
properties.description: A Medieval tower located on Tiber Island.

properties.name: Roman castrum at Pyrgi
properties.description: The Roman castrum at Pyrgi seems to re-use, in a direct fashion, elements of the preceding Etruscan city plan, although covering a smaller area.

properties.name: Dinka Settlement Complex
properties.description: A small frontier settlement dated to the Neo-Asssyrian period, located in the Peshdar Plain near the banks of the Lesser Zab River.

properties.name: Villa Redenta
properties.description: An ancient suburban villa outside of Spoletium, occupied from the Augustan period to the third century A.D. The remains are on the grounds of the modern Villa Redenta complex.

properties.name: Nether Denton Roman fort
properties.description: A Roman fort site at Nether Denton that was identified via cropmarks. The fort formed part of the Stanegate frontier system, and thus pre-dates Hadrian's Wall. It was abandoned ca. 122.

properties.name: Villa of L. Crassius Tertius
properties.description: The Villa of L. Crassius Tertius at Oplontis (modern Torre Annunziata in Italy) was discovered in 1974, approximately 250m east of the Villa of Poppaea.

properties.name: Forum of Paestum
properties.description: The forum of Roman Paestum stands north of the Hera sanctuary and measures ca. 57 x 150 meters. It occupies the site of the Greek agora and was surrounded with a peristyle of re-used Doric columns. Tabernae stood at its south side and baths funded by M. Tullius Venneianus stood to the southwest. A triple-podium structure - lararium? - stands on the western side.

properties.name: Lake Tana
properties.description: Lake Tana is the source of the Blue Nile and the largest lake in Ethiopia.

properties.name: Temple of Hera, Olympia
properties.description: The Temple of Hera at Olympia, also known as the Heraion, is a peripteral temple in the northwest corner of the Altis precinct that is dedicated to Hera. Built ca. 600-590 B.C., the Heraion is the oldest temple at Olympia and one of the earliest known examples of the Doric order in Greece.

properties.name: Pergamum
properties.description: An important ancient settlement, located at modern Bergama in Turkey. It was first described in Xenophon's Anabasis and was later used as a treasury under Lysimachus. Pergamum became the administrative capital and principal city of the Attalid kingdom and dynasty (282-133 BCE) and was briefly the first capital of the Roman province of Asia. It later was a seat of a Christian bishopric and is listed in Revelation as one of the seven churches of Asia. It was inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2014 under Pergamon and its Multi-Layered Cultural Landscape.

properties.name: Apesas (mountain)
properties.description: Mount Aphesas, now Mount Phoukas, separated the terriroty of Kleonai from the Corinthia. It is connected with the myth of the Nemean lion and was the site of an ash altar sacred to Zeus in use from the Geometric period to the fourth century B.C.

properties.name: Arachnaion (mountain)
properties.description: A mountain of the Argolid with a higher western peak (Profitis Ilias, 1199 masl) and a lower eastern peak (Mavrovouni or Arna, 1139 masl). Material from the Mycenaean, Archaic, and Classical periods has been found on the western peak and identified with altars of Zeus and Hera described by Pausanias. Aeschylus mentions its use as a signal station.

properties.name: Arcadia
properties.description: The ancient region of Arcadia comprised the highlands at the center of the Peloponnese.

properties.name: Argolis
properties.description: Argolis (also known as 'the Argolid') occupied the eastern part of the Peloponnese; comprising primarily the Argolid peninsula and the coastal region lying to the east of Arcadia, and north of Laconia.

properties.name: Tomb of Caius Cartilius Poplicola
properties.description: The Tomb of Caius Cartilius Poplicola, dating to ca. 30-20 B.C., is a monumental tomb outside the Porta Marina of Ostia. Poplicola was a prominent citizen of Ostia.

properties.name: Villa Romana di Collesecco
properties.description: A villa rustica located in the Sabina, ca. 1 km from Cottanello (Rieti). The imperial villa was superimposed over a villa of the republican period.

properties.name: Tuttul
properties.description: Tuttul was a Bronze Age city that is associated with the archaeological site of Tell Bi'a located in the Raqqa Governorate of northern Syria. The tell lies near the confluence of the Balikh and Euphrates rivers.

properties.name: Qasr al-Abd at Tyrus
properties.description: A Hellenistic palace constructed in the second century CE at the southern end of the Tyrus/'Iraq al-Amir site.

properties.name: Ponte Valentino
properties.description: A Roman bridge located east of Benevento, Italy, and built by Flavius Iulius Valens.

properties.name: Necropolis of Ponte Messato
properties.description: A pre-Roman and Roman period necropolis on the outskirts of Teramo.

properties.name: Mahabodhi Temple
properties.description: One of the four main Buddhist pilgrimage sites, identified as the place where Gautama Buddha attained Enlightenment. The first temple on the site was built by Emperor Asoka in the third century B.C., and the present temple dates from the fifth or sixth centuries. It is one of the earliest Buddhist temples built entirely in brick, still standing in India, from the late Gupta period. The site was largely abandoned from the twelfth-eighteenth centuries. It was named a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2002.

properties.name: Stadium of Delos
properties.description: Stadium in the settlement of Delos, constructed in the early 3rd century BCE.

properties.name: Anmurru
properties.description: A fortress in the vicinity of Til-garimmu fortified by the Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721-705 BC) against Uraru1e6du.

properties.name: Kammanu/Meliddu (kingdom)
properties.description: A kingdom in eastern Anatolia, whose capital is classical Melitene (modern Arslantepe). Meliddu, which is sometimes referred to as Kammanu, was conquered by the eighth-century-BC Assyrian king Sargon II and its territory was given to Kummuhu.

properties.name: Hilakku (region)
properties.description: Hilakku is a mountainous region near Tabu0101lu and Que in the Cilician plain. Its exact location is still debated among scholars. Nevertheless, Hilakku has been tentatively identified as being in the area of Bolkar Dau011flaru0131 or in that of Gu00f6ksu-Tal, in the western part of Cilicia, that is, in the classical Cilicia Tracheia/Cilicia Aspera.

properties.name: Sam'alla (kingdom)
properties.description: Sam'alla (u0161mu02bel; also known as Bu012bt-Gabbu0101ri and yu02bedy) was a small Aramean kingdom/city-state during the first half of the first millennium BC. It is named after its capital city Sam'al (modern Zincirli Hu00f6yu00fck).

properties.name: Tomb of Publius Vesonius Phileros
properties.description: An aedicula tomb built near the Porta Nocera ca. A.D. 25-50 by Publius Vesonius Phileros for himself, his patroness Vesonia, and his friend Marcus Orfellius Faustus. A later added inscription shows a falling out between the two friends.

properties.name: Carranque
properties.description: A palatial complex that includes a villa originally built during the fourth century, Carranque also has significant Visigothic and Christian phases.

properties.name: Saqqarah
properties.description: A pharaonic necropolis serving the ancient Egyptian city of Memphis. It was most active during Early Dynastic and Old Kingdom Egypt. The step pyramid complex of the Third Dynasty Pharaoh Djoser is the best preserved and most well known structure of the site.

properties.name: Dehistan/Mishrian
properties.description: The ruined Medieval city of Dehistan/Mashhad-i Misrian is now located in the Balkan Region of western Turkmenistan. It flourished from the tenth to fourteenth centuries along a major trade network.

properties.name: Villa of Agrippa
properties.description: The so-called Villa (or baths) of Agrippa on Planasia Ins. (modern Pianosa) is the putative location of exile for Agrippa Postumus, grandson of Augustus.

properties.name: Aku012btu-Temple of Iu0161tar
properties.description: The New Yearu2019s House (or Aku012btu Temple) of Nineveh's tutelary deity Iu0161tar appears to date back at least to the Middle Assyrian period (reign of Tukultu012b-Ninurta I). Its Sumerian ceremonial name is not preserved in extant cuneiform sources. This temple's exact location remains unknown and it is certain whether Iu0161tar's Aku012btu Temple was located in the citadel or in the lower town.

properties.name: Citadel Wall of Nineveh
properties.description: The citadel of Nineveh was surrounded by a thick mud-brick wall. When the 7th-century B.C. king Sennacherib made Nineveh the capital of the Assyrian empire, that wall was rebuilt and strengthened; its base was reinforced with limestone blocks along its southern stretch.

properties.name: Sirkap
properties.description: A Graeco-Bactrian city founded ca. 180 B.C. by the king Demetrius.

properties.name: So-called Tempio di Venere e Cupido
properties.description: The so-called Temple of Venus and Cupid at Rome is part of the complex of buildings associated with the Sessorian palace. The structure's modern assignation is owed to the discovery of a fragmentary statue of Sallustia Orbiana in the guise of Venus Felix. Sallustia Orbiana was the wife of Alexander Severus. The statue is now held in the Museo Pio Clementino in the Vatican Museums.

properties.name: Canopus at Hadrian's Villa
properties.description: The Canopus garden is set at the principal entrance to Hadrian's Villa. An imposing waterway occupies all its length.

properties.name: Formello villa and mausoleum
properties.description: A Roman villa in the territory of Blera of which a cistern and a mausoleum remain.

properties.name: Oram's Arbour
properties.description: In Oram's Arbour, now a park, are the remains of an Iron Age hill-fort.

properties.name: Via Collatina
properties.description: A Roman road connecting Rome with Collatia.

properties.name: Via Tiburtina
properties.description: An ancient road heading east-northeast from Rome to Tibur.

properties.name: Withdrawn (duplicate): Seabegs Wood
properties.description: This place resource is a duplicate for http://pleiades.stoa.org/places/89287 and was erroneously created and published. It has been withdrawn and moved to errata.

properties.name: Gibil Gabib
properties.description: Gibil Gabib is an archaeological site on a high mountain (615 m asl) in Sicily with evidence for long-range occupation stretching from prehistoric times to the Hellenistic period.

properties.name: Arian Baptistry
properties.description: Baptistry built by Theodoric the Great in the late fifth or early sixth century AD

properties.name: New Basilica of Saint Apollinaris
properties.description: A basilica in Ravenna, Italy, erected by Theodoric the Great in the first quarter of the sixth century AD.

properties.name: Woden Law hill fort
properties.description: Woden Law hill fort is a multi-vallate Iron Age site in Scotland.

properties.name: Monterozzi necropolis
properties.description: The Monterozzi necropolis is an Etruscan necropolis located to the east of Tarquinia. The necropolis contains about 6,000 graves.

properties.name: Via Campana?
properties.description: A road located on the right bank of the Tiber leading to the Campus Salinarum romanarum and sharing the first part of its course with the Via Portuensis.

properties.name: Basilica of Santa Maria in Trastevere
properties.description: The Basilica di Santa Maria in Trastevere is a titular minor basilica located in the Trastevere district of Rome, Italy.

properties.name: Roman amphitheater of Italica
properties.description: The amphitheater of Italica, built in the second century A.D., was one of the largest in the Roman world and could accommodate an estimated 25,000 spectators.

properties.name: Italia, Regio I
properties.description: One of the administrative regions from Augustus's division of Italy, comprising Latium and Campania. Described by Pliny the Elder in Book III of his Natural History.

properties.name: Great Mosque of Aleppo
properties.description: The Great Mosque of Aleppo, also known as the Umayyad Mosque of Aleppo, is the largest and one of the oldest mosques in the city of Aleppo, Syria.

properties.name: Tomb of the Volumnii and Palazzone necropolis
properties.description: A hypogeum-type tomb located in Ponte San Giovanni, a suburb of Perugia. The tomb is generally dated to the third century B.C.

properties.name: Fayyum (oasis)
properties.description: Large depression (not a true oasis) west of the Nile River containing arable land watered by the flooding of the Nile. Inhabited from the Mesolithic period, the Fayyum contains the earliest evidence of farming in Egypt. The water levels of the Fayyum's lake varied significantly until a land reclamation project during the 12th dynasty implemented artificial water controls. During the Ptolemaic and Roman periods, the Fayyum was administered as the Arsinoite Nome.

properties.name: Quartier du Stade at Delos
properties.description: Neighborhood surrounding the stadium in the settlement of Delos, constructed during the Hellenistic period.

properties.name: Arch of Trajan at Ancona
properties.description: An arch erected to honor Trajan between A.D. 100 and 116.

properties.name: Topazios (island)
properties.description: An island in the Red Sea. The island is noted by Pliny as a source of topaz.

properties.name: Villa rustica of Szentendre-Skanzen
properties.description: A so-called Roman Villa Rustica covering some 5,200 square meters located at the Szabadtu00e9ri Nu00e9prajzi Mu00fazeum (Skanzen), Szentendre.

properties.name: Du017eanfida
properties.description: Du017eanfida is a village located in the Armavir province of southwestern Armenia, ca. 9 km south of Sardarabat. Here a stone block with an inscription of Sarduri II (8th century BCE) was found which curses anyone who dares to damage or destroy his fortress or inscription.

properties.name: Vetricella
properties.description: An Early Medieval royal property located in the area of Scarlino (Grosseto) in Tuscany.

properties.name: Bernashivka
properties.description: Site of a settlement from the Neolithic Cucuteni-Trypillia culture, located on the left bank of the Dniester River.

properties.name: Morgantina, House of Ganymede
properties.description: The House of Ganymede at Morgantina is a peristyle house with mosaic floor pavements. The earliest phase of the house belongs to the third century B.C.

properties.name: Ekklesiasterion of Morgantina
properties.description: The monumental central staircase in the agora of Morgantina has been identified as the Ekklesiasterion. They date after the middle of the third century B.C.

properties.name: Theater of Stratos
properties.description: The Theater of Stratos dates to the late fourth century B.C.

properties.name: Angkor Wat
properties.description: The principal temple of Angkor, the capital city of the Khmer empire, Angkor Wat was constructed in the 12th century CE. Angkor was inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1992.

properties.name: Temple of Dionysos at Teos
properties.description: A Temple of Dionysos in the Ionic order begun in the Hellenistic period.

properties.name: Thermae Diocletiani
properties.description: Public baths near the Viminal Hill in Rome constructed under Diocletian from 298-306 CE.

properties.name: Eurmeiminanki
properties.description: The ziggurat of the god the god Nabu00fb at Borsippa. The Sumerian ceremonial name Eurmeiminanki means House which Gathers the Seven (Me's) of Heaven and Underworld.

properties.name: Elugalgalgasisa
properties.description: The ziggurat of the god Su00een at Ur. The Sumerian ceremonial name Elugalgalgasisa means House of the King who Lets Counsel Flourish. The platform temple was originally built during the Early Bronze Age and was then restored in the sixth century B.C. by King Nabonidus.

properties.name: Ebabbar
properties.description: The temple of the god u0160amau0161 at Sippar. The Sumerian ceremonial name Ebabbar means Shining House.

properties.name: Insula 104 at Hierapolis
properties.description: A well-excavated residential section of the Phrygian city of Hierapolis, dated to the proto-Byzantine period (ca. 2nd century CE).

properties.name: Roman amphitheater at Uthina
properties.description: The Roman amphitheater at Uthina dates to the reign of Hadrian and seated about 16,000 spectators.

properties.name: tribus Velina
properties.description: The tribus Velina was one of the later rural tribes which was established in Rome in 241 B.C.

properties.name: Via Flaminia
properties.description: A major Roman road connecting Rome and Ariminum, by way of Narnia and Nuceria. The road was begun under the censorship of Caius Flaminius Nepos in 220 B.C.

properties.name: Giza
properties.description: The site of Giza encompasses the Giza Necropolis, a large archaeological site famous for its pyramid complexes and monumental sculpture.

properties.name: Temple of Jupiter Anxur
properties.description: A late Republican sanctuary of the city of Terracina that is typically dated ca. 100-70 B.C.

properties.name: Review Palace
properties.description: An Assyrian armory was built to the south of the citadel at Nineveh. The ruins of the 7th-century B.C. architectural complex are directly below the modern settlement built on top of Nebi Yunus, the site's smaller mound.

properties.name: Palace of Naqi'a
properties.description: The influential Neo-Assyrian queen Naqiu2019a built a royal residence for her son Esarhaddon in the citadel of Nineveh. This palace, which may have served as a summer residence for the Assyrian king and his mother, remains unlocated. It is certain from contemporary Akkadian inscriptions that the palace was constructed near the Su00een-u0160amau0161 temple, but the exact location of that temple is not known.

properties.name: Royal Road of Nineveh
properties.description: As part of transformation of Ninevehu2019s lower town at the beginning of the 7th century B.C., the Neo-Assyrian king Sennacherib created a broad royal road that ran all the way through the city. That fifty-two-cubit-wide road, whose ancient ceremonial name is not known, is still unlocated, but it is generally thought to have run north from the Au0161u0161ur Gate, east past the armory and the citadel, to the Su00een Gate (formerly the Gate of the Gardens).

properties.name: Roman Circus (Bosra)
properties.description: The Roman circus of Bosra dates to the third century.

properties.name: San Nicola in Carcere
properties.description: San Nicola in Carcere is a titular church in Rome's historical district (rione) Sant'Angelo, close to the Forum Boarium. The twelfth century church is built atop the remains of Roman temples of the Forum Holitorium and incorporates their remains into its structure.

properties.name: Sintashta
properties.description: Bronze Age archaeological site east of the Ural Mountains. The type site of the Sintashta Culture, it was inhabited from approximately 2800-1600 BCE.

properties.name: Sanctuary of Pan at Paneas
properties.description: The Paneion at Caesarea Philippi, a sanctuary site dedicated to Pan centered around a natural cave and spring site on the southwestern slopess of Mount Hermon. The sanctuary was first built in the Hellenistic period (before 200 BCE). A temple to Augustus was constructed in front of the cave during the reign of Herod the Great in 19 BCE, and the site was further expanded through 220 CE.

properties.name: Maleses
properties.description: A pre-Roman Iberian settlement

properties.name: Cerreto Sannita
properties.description: A Samnite temple dedicated to Flora.

properties.name: Esquilinus Mons
properties.description: The Esquiline Hill is one of the seven hills of Rome. The eastern section of the hill lay outside the Servian Wall, and served as a pauper's cemetery during the archaic and Republican periods.

properties.name: Grotta Porcina tumulus
properties.description: A rock-cut tumulus of the first half of the sixth century B.C.

properties.name: Macchia delle Valli, Vetralla
properties.description: A rock-cut Etrusco-Roman sanctuary sacred to Demeter that was discovered during rescue excavations in 2006 following looting activity. The sanctuary, set in a grove, remained in use until the second century A.D.

properties.name: Orcia (river)
properties.description: The Orcia originates on Monte Cetona and is a major tributary of the Ombrone.

properties.name: Abbazia di Sant'Antimo
properties.description: The Abbey of Sant'Antimo was a Benedictine monastery located in the comune of Montalcino, Italy, about 9 km from the line of the Via Francigena. The abbey grew around the site of an oratory to Saint Anthimus, whose relics may have been relocated here in the eighth century. The site was formerly occupied by a Roman villa.

properties.name: Pons Sublicius
properties.description: The Pons Sublicius is traditionally held to be the earliest Roman bridge across the river Tiber. The textual tradition assigns its construction to the king Ancus Marcius in 642 B.C. It crossed the Tiber near the Forum Boarium just downstream from the Tiber Island.

properties.name: Castle of Serravalle
properties.description: The Castle of Serravalle is a twelfth century castle located in Bosa, province of Oristano, Sardinia. It is connected with the Tuscan Malaspina family.

properties.name: Forum Augusti
properties.description: The Forum of Augustus at Rome was dedicated in 2 BCE, to the northeast of Julius Caesar's Forum. It contained the Temple of Mars Ultor.

properties.name: Pano Mantilaris
properties.description: Site of a late Bronze Age settlement near the modern village of Alassa, southern Cyprus.

properties.name: Paliotaverna
properties.description: Site of a late Bronze Age settlement near the modern village of Alassa, southern Cyprus.

properties.name: Tabru012bz
properties.description: A place from the TAVO Index

properties.name: Tirzah
properties.description: Tell el-Far'ah (North) is an archaeological site northeast of the modern-day town of Nablus, identified with the Biblical town of Tirzah. The tell shows signs of inhabitation from the Neolithic Period through the Iron Age.

properties.name: Roman baths of Ebora
properties.description: The Roman baths of Ebora were in use during the second and third centuries. The archaeological site was discovered in 1987.

properties.name: Novaya Beden'ga I
properties.description: Hillfort site in the watershed between the Volga and Sviyaga rivers. The site shows signs of habitation in the Late Scythian period (1st-3rd centuries CE) and the Hunnish period (4th-6th centuries CE).

properties.name: Temple of Apollo at Thermos
properties.description: A temple to the Apollo built in the late seventh century B.C. atop the ruins of the previous megaron in Thermos.

properties.name: So-called East Church in Apollonia
properties.description: A Christian church located in the ancient city of Apollonia (Cyrenaica) built approximately in the fifth century A.D., probably on earlier Hellenistic foundations. The site was excavated in 1922 and shows a three-aisled nave with transept at the eastern end, and a single apse. Traces of the mosaic floor are still visible.

properties.name: S. Porphyrius
properties.description: The oldest Orthodox church in Gaza, sacred to the fifth century Saint Porphyrius whose tomb lies within the church.

properties.name: Deprecated Skylax fl.
properties.description: This Pleiades place resource was moved to errata because it is a doublet for another place resource (see details for link).

properties.name: Tell el-u02bbAbd
properties.description: Mound site along the eastern bank of the Euphrates in northern Syria. The site shows signs of habitation from the Early Bronze Age through the Byzantine period. Tell el-u02bbAbd was flooded by the construction of the Taqba Dam in 1975, though a portion of it has reemerged due to declining water levels in Lake Assad.

properties.name: Altyn-Depe
properties.description: Large settlement of the late Neolothic period through the Bronze Age located in modern Turkmenistan. Part of the Bactriau2013Margiana Archaeological Complex, Altyn-Depe was a major urban center of Bronze Age Central Asia.

properties.name: La Lu00f4ne arcade, Nimes aqueduct
properties.description: A segment of the Nimes aqueduct.

properties.name: Doulopolis
properties.description: A community within the territory of Colophon. Although there is some controversy as to its status, the name suggests that the community was founded by slaves (or other dissidents) who supported Aristonikos against Rome between 133 and 130/129 BCE. It seems to have been reabsorbed by Colophon at an undetermined point after 130/129. Its location is unknown today.

properties.name: Ku0131nu0131k Hu00f6yu00fck
properties.description: An archaeological site in southern Cappadocia. Inhabited from the Late Bronze Age through the Middle Iron Age, Ku0131nu0131k Hu00f6yu00fck was an important settlement in the Kingdom of Tuwana.

properties.name: Kinneil
properties.description: The site of a Roman fortlet on the Antonine Wall. The fortlet measures ca. 21.5 x 18.5 m, covering an area of ca. 0.04 ha.

properties.name: San Pietro di Cantoni Italic sanctuary
properties.description: An extra-urban Italic sanctuary located in the territory of ancient Saepinum.

properties.name: Coriglia, Castel Viscardo
properties.description: An Etrusco-Roman settlement.

properties.name: Tell Jerablus Tahtani
properties.description: Jerablus Tahtani is a multi-period settlement located south of Carchemish. Excavation has revealed evidence related to the Uruk expansion in the fourth millennium B.C. as well as evidence of the second urban revolution in Early Bronze Age Syria. The Bronze Age fortified site is built atop remains of a third millennium B.C. phase. Numerous tombs and stratified mortuary deposits have been excavated, including a prominent tomb near the entrance to the Bronze Age settlement.

properties.name: Gabbutu016bnu
properties.description: A town mentioned in Neo-Assyrian sources; the modern site is Gibbetu00f4n. An alternative name is Rau02bes Abu012b u1e24amu012bd.

properties.name: So-called Theatre 3
properties.description: A Roman theatre on the acropolis ridge of Cyrene, conventionally numbered 3.

properties.name: Amberd
properties.description: A 10th-century fortress located on Mount Aragats in modern Aragatsotn province, Armenia.

properties.name: Kecharis
properties.description: Armenian monastery dated to the 11th-13th centuries CE.

properties.name: Hovhannavank
properties.description: Medieval Armenian monastery in the village of Ohanavan, Aragatsotn Province, Armenia. The site originated as a single-nave church in the 4th century CE, was expanded in the 4th-5th centuries, and was substantially renovated in the 17th-18th centuries.

properties.name: Makaravank'
properties.description: Medieval Armenian church and monastic complex dated to the 9th-13th centuries.

properties.name: Cathedral of the Holy Cross at Aghtamar
properties.description: Armenian church built on the island of Aghtamar by King Gagik I Artsruni between 915-921 CE.

properties.name: Akdamar Island
properties.description: The second largest of the four islands in Lake Van, in eastern Turkey.

properties.name: Hadrian's Wall (Cumbrian Coast)
properties.description: Line of Roman fortifications along Cumbrian Coast running from western terminus of the stone wall commonly referred to as Hadrian's Wall at Maia (Bowness-on-Solway) in the north to Gabrosentum (Moresby) in the south.

properties.name: Staranzano, Roman villa u201cLiberta Peticiau201d
properties.description: A Roman villa of the mid-first century A.D.

properties.name: Afyonkarahisar Castle
properties.description: Afyonkarahisar Castle is a Late Bronze Age fort (ca. 1350 B.C.) and may be the site of the Hittite settlement known as Hapanuwa.

properties.name: Lago dell'Accesa (lake)
properties.description: Lago dell'Accesa is a lake located in the Colline Metallifere.

properties.name: Theater at Letoon
properties.description: An ancient theater associated with the Letoon, a sanctuary of Leto near the ancient city Xanthos in Lycia. The theater is located on the Roman agora, to the the north of the acropolis.

properties.name: Roman amphitheater at Corinth
properties.description: The Roman amphitheater at Corinth was located northeast of the Temple of Apollo. It has been suggested that it dates to the early days of the Roman colony, perhaps placing its construction in the first century B.C.

properties.name: Murus Servii Tullii
properties.description: The Republican city wall of Rome.

properties.name: Necropolis of Montessu
properties.description: The Necropolis of Montessu is located near Villaperuccio, Sardinia. It is the site of about 40 domus de Janas tombs and dates to the third millennium B.C.

properties.name: Du00fan Aonghasa
properties.description: A prehistoric fort in the Aran Islands of County Galway, Ireland, dating ca. 1100 BC.

properties.name: Mega Pedion
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 69 B4 Mega Pedion

properties.name: Oulatha
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 69 C3 Oulatha

properties.name: Pella/Berenice/Philippeia
properties.description: Pella/Berenice/Philippeia (Tabaqat Fahl (u0637u0628u0642u0629 u0641u062du0644)) is a ruined ancient city located in northwestern Jordan. Pella was continuously occupied from the Neolithic period until its destruction by means of an earthquake in AD 749.

properties.name: Idumaea
properties.description: Idumaea or the kingdom of Edom was an historical region of the Levant located south of Iudaea and the Dead Sea.

properties.name: Iordanes (river)
properties.description: Iordanes fl. (the Jordan river).

properties.name: Iudaea (region)
properties.description: Iudaea was an historical region of the Levant located in the mountainous southern part of the Land of Palestine, roughly corresponding to the southern West Bank. The region's name derives from the biblical tribe of Judah and the associated Kingdom of Judah (ca. 934 until 586 BC).

properties.name: Masada
properties.description: Masada is a natural fortress in the Iudaean desert that overlooks the Dead Sea. It was the site of the standoff between Jewish rebels and the Roman army in A.D. 73. Herod the Great built a palace atop the citadel during his reign. Roman camps and siege works are still visible at the site, which is listed on the UNESCO World Heritage List.

properties.name: Negev
properties.description: The Negev is a desert and semidesert region of southern Israel.

properties.name: Palaestina (region)
properties.description: A region at the southeastern coast of the Mediterranean Sea, encompassing the coastal plain between Phoenicia and Gaza. The region's name derives from the Hebrew Plu0161th, the land of the Philistines.

properties.name: Saltus Constantinianus?
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 70 E3 Saltus Constantinianus?

properties.name: Saltus Gerariticus
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 70 F3 Saltus Gerariticus

properties.name: Serbonitis L.
properties.description: A large, saline lake in Egypt on the north coast of the Sinai Peninsula; the Serbonian Bog described by Herodotus.

properties.name: Shephela
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 70 F2 Shephela

properties.name: Sobata
properties.description: Sobata or Shivta is an ancient city in the Negev Desert located some 43 km southwest of Beersheba. The site was enrolled as a UNESCO World Heritage site, together with Haluza, Mamshit, and Avdat, in June 2005.

properties.name: Thala
properties.description: Thala (Tell Halif) is a small tell located in the northeastern Negev desert, near the modern town of Lahav. The site shows signs of habitation from the Chalcolithic through the Medieval and Ottoman periods.

properties.name: Au0161u0161ur-muu0161albir-palu00ea-u0161arri-u0113piu0161u012bu0161u-nu0101u1e63ir-ummu0101nu012bu0161u
properties.description: The Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721u2013705 BC) surrounded his new capital Du016br-u0160arruku012bn (Fort Sargon) with a rectangular-shaped, 16,280-cubit-long inner and outer city wall. The name of the city wall (du016bru) was Au0161u0161ur-muu0161albir-palu00ea-u0161arri-u0113piu0161u012bu0161u-nu0101u1e63ir-ummu0101nu012bu0161u (The God Au0161u0161ur Is the One Who Prolongs the Reign of Its Royal Builder (and) Protects His Troops) according to some Akkadian royal inscriptions, but Au0161u0161ur-mulabbir-palu00ea-u0161arri-u0113piu0161u012bu0161u-nu0101u1e63ir-peru02beu012bu0161u (The God Au0161u0161ur Is the One Who Prolongs the Reign of Its Royal Builder (and) Protects His Offspring) according to other texts written in the name of Sargon II.

properties.name: u0160amau0161 Gate
properties.description: The u0160amau0161 Gate, which was given the Akkadian ceremonial name u0160amau0161-muu0161aku0161id-ernittu012bya (The God u0160amau0161 Is the One Who Makes Me Triumph), is the first of the eight city gates of Du016br-u0160arruku012bn (Fort Sargon) listed by Sargon II (r. 721u2013705 BC) in inscriptions recording the construction of his new capital. This gate is the first of the east-facing entrances to the city.

properties.name: Enlil Gate
properties.description: The Enlil Gate, which was given the Akkadian ceremonial name Enlil-muku012bn-iu0161du012b-alu012bya (The God Enlil Is the One Who Establishes the Foundation of My City), is the third of the eight city gates of Du016br-u0160arruku012bn (Fort Sargon) listed by Sargon II (r. 721u2013705 BC) in inscriptions recording the construction of his new capital. This gate is the first of the north-facing entrances to the city.

properties.name: Ea Gate
properties.description: The Ea Gate, which was given the Akkadian ceremonial name Ea-muu0161tu0113u0161ir-nagbu012bu0161u (The God Ea Is the One Who Keeps Its Spring(s) in Good Order), is the seventh of the eight city gates of Du016br-u0160arruku012bn (Fort Sargon) listed by Sargon II (r. 721u2013705 BC) in inscriptions recording the construction of his new capital. This gate is the first of the south-facing entrances to the city, but its precise location remains unknown.

properties.name: Bu0113let-ilu012b Gate
properties.description: The Bu0113let-ilu012b Gate, which was given the Akkadian ceremonial name Bu0113let-ilu012b-murappiu0161at-talittu012bu0161u (The Goddess Bu0113let-ilu012b Is the One Who Increases Its (Animalsu2019) Offspring), is the eighth of the eight city gates of Du016br-u0160arruku012bn (Fort Sargon) listed by Sargon II (r. 721u2013705 BC) in inscriptions recording the construction of his new capital. This gate is the second of the south-facing entrances to the city, but its precise location remains unknown.

properties.name: Fosso Marangone
properties.description: A small stream that flows into the Tyrrhenian Sea. It now lies in the territory of the municipalities of Allumiere, Civitavecchia, and Santa Marinella and forms the geographical boundary between the latter two. The watercourse originates at Poggio Ombricolo.

properties.name: Cisterns of La Maalga
properties.description: A group of 15 large cisterns constructed during the late Punic era as a water supply for the city of Carthage.

properties.name: Samnite House
properties.description: The so-called Samnite House is a domus in Herculaneum that originally dates to the second century B.C., making it one of the oldest buildings discovered at the site.

properties.name: Temple of Artemis at Ephesus
properties.description: The Temple of Artemis, the central element of the extramural sanctuary of Artemis at Ephesus, was considered one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.

properties.name: Odeon at Kom el-Dikka
properties.description: The Odeon at Kom el-Dikka, used both for entertainment and academic functions, was built in the center of ancient Alexandria in the fourth century CE and rebuilt between the end of the fifth and beginning of the sixth century CE.

properties.name: Arch of Septimius Severus
properties.description: The Arch of Septimius Severus is situated at the northwest corner of the Forum Romanum. It was dedicated in A.D. 203 and serves to commemorate the Parthian victories of Emperor Septimius Severus and his two sons against the Parthians (194/195 and 197u2013199).

properties.name: Philistia (region)
properties.description: A region in the southern Levant inhabited by the Philistines in the Iron Age. The Philistine Pentapolis comprised Ashdod, Ashkelon, Gaza, Ekron, and Gath.

properties.name: Via Portuensis?
properties.description: The Via Portuensis is an ancient Roman road that connected Rome and Portus. It proceeded along the right bank of the Tiber river, starting from the Pons Aemilius. In the first part of its course it is identical to the Via Campana.

properties.name: Jerwan Aqueduct
properties.description: The Assyrian king Sennacherib had an aqueduct constructed between 703 and 690 B.C. near the ancient city of Girmua. The structure is part of the Khinnis [Canal] System. The identification of the structure's builder is confirmed by means of several inscriptions.

properties.name: Roman amphitheater at Richborough
properties.description: The earthwork remains of the Roman amphitheater associated with the Saxon Shore fort at Richborough.

properties.name: Terrace and altar of M. Nonius Balbus
properties.description: Marcus Nonius Balbus of Nuceria was an important civic patron of Herculaneum. Balbus was a praetor and proconsul of Crete and Cyrene and served as tribune of the plebs in 32 B.C. This architectural complex near the Suburban Baths included the terrace as well as an honorific statue and altar.

properties.name: Amphitheater of the Three Gauls
properties.description: The Sanctuary of the Three Gauls (Tres Galliae) was a late first century B.C. sanctuary in Lugdunum; the amphitheater dates to 19 B.C.

properties.name: Sopka-2
properties.description: A burial site on the banks of the Om River in western Siberia containing a number of non-contemporaneous Bronze Age tombs.

properties.name: Roman theater of Fourviu00e8re
properties.description: A Roman theater in Lyon, France, that originally dates ca. 15 B.C.

properties.name: Acarnanian League
properties.description: The Acarnanian League was a tribal confederation of the Acarnanians that later transformed into a league by the 5th century BCE. The league was incorporated into the Roman province of Achaea following the battle of Actium in 31 BCE.

properties.name: Tell Uqair
properties.description: The archaeological site of Tell Uqair, ancient name unknown, is noted for its Uruk period architecture. This includes a small tripartite temple that stands on an irregular platform.

properties.name: Mortuary Temple of Amenhotep III
properties.description: Temple constructed in the Theban Necropolis during the 18th Dynasty.

properties.name: Qattara?/Karana?
properties.description: Tell al-Rimah, is the site of a settlement inhabited from the third to first millennium BCE that has been identified as the site of either Qattara or Karana.

properties.name: Caupona and Domus of L. Vetutius Placidus and Ascula
properties.description: Thermopolium with a marble counter (I.8.8), connected to a private house (I.8.9) in Regio I, insula 8 in Pompeii. The walls of the house show extensive decoration in third style.

properties.name: House of the Four Styles
properties.description: The House of the Four Styles or Casa dei Quattro Stili (I.8.17) is noted for having examples of all four style of Pompeian wall paintings.

properties.name: Roman Aqueduct at Moria
properties.description: The remains of a 26 km aqueduct that supplied Mytilene. The best preserved section measures some 170 m. long.

properties.name: Aphrodision
properties.description: Located outside the city walls of Pergamon, this temple, according to an inscription (OGIS 273-9), was supposedly the site of a victory of Attalos I over the Tolistogi, Galatians, and Antiochus Hierax. it was likely later destroyed by Philip V.

properties.name: Longthorpe
properties.description: A Roman fortress of the mid-first century A.D.

properties.name: Mount Judi
properties.description: Mount Judi (also al-u01e6u016bdiyy, Cu00fbdu00eeu200e, Cudi), also spelled Guti and Kutu, is a mountain where Sennacherib had several monuments carved. The Neo-Assyrian name is Mount Nipur.

properties.name: Arslantepe (Melid)
properties.description: Arslantepe became an important center in the Late Chalcolithic period. With the decline of the Hittite empire, the site became the center of an independent Luwian Neo-Hittite state (Kammanu). The state became a tributary of the Assyrian empire under Tiglath-Pileser I (1115-1077 BC) and it was sacked by Sargon II in 712 BC.

properties.name: Bur-mar'ina
properties.description: A town mentioned in Neo-Assyrian sources that is identified with brmrn in Aramaic texts and the modern Tell Shuyukh Fawqani.

properties.name: Tigellio Roman villa
properties.description: An elite villa dated to the first century B.C.

properties.name: Beit Shemesh
properties.description: City 30 km west of Jerusalem inhabited from the Bronze Age until its destruction in 701 CE.

properties.name: Temple of Herakles, Cora
properties.description: The Temple of Herakles at Cora was built during the 80s B.C. The temple is tetrastyle in its plan and built following the Etrusco-Italic temple tradition.

properties.name: Abu Ballas
properties.description: A sandstone peak approximately 200 kilometers southwest of the Dakleh Oasis containing extensive pottery remains dated from the 3rd millennium BCE through the Roman period. Abu Ballas was likely a way station along a caravan route connecting the Dakhleh Oasis with Gilf Kebir.

properties.name: Dongola
properties.description: The late antique capital of the Nubian state of Makuria, Dongola remained an important center of trade through the medieval period.

properties.name: tribus Stellatina
properties.description: The tribus Stellatina was a later rural tribe of ancient Rome which was established in 387 B.C.

properties.name: Mochlos archaeological site
properties.description: A multi-period settlement site in use by a number of civilizations dating ca. 3100 B.C. to A.D. 1200.

properties.name: Theater of Orchomenus
properties.description: A theater of the late fourth century B.C.

properties.name: Eetioneia Hellenistic gateway
properties.description: A fortified gateway protecting the mouth of the Piraeus harbor.

properties.name: Castle of Bominaco
properties.description: A castle at Bominaco in Italy that originally dates to the twelfth century.

properties.name: Central Baths
properties.description: A bath complex (IX, 4, 5-18) located at the intersection of the Via Stabiana and Via di Nola that was built following the earthquake of AD 62.

properties.name: Harmatos Pr.
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 56 D4 Harmatos Pr.

properties.name: Hyllos (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 56 G4 Hyllos fl.

properties.name: Hyllos? (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 56 G4 Hyllos? fl.

properties.name: Hyrcanius Campus
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 56 F4 Hyrcanius Campus

properties.name: Ida (mountain)
properties.description: Ida M. is a mountain of northwestern Turkey standing to 5,820 ft (1,774 m) above sea level.

properties.name: Ilium/Troia
properties.description: An ancient city of northwest Anatolia with occupation ranging from the Bronze Age to the Roman period. Troy features as the central setting of Homer's Iliad.

properties.name: Indeipedion
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 56 F3 Indeipedion

properties.name: Ionia (region)
properties.description: The coast of Asia Minor between Aeolis and Caria.

properties.name: Kaleon (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 56 E5 Kaleon fl.

properties.name: Kanaites (river)

properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 56 G4 Kissos? fl.

properties.name: Klazomenai (later)
properties.description: A town in Lydia that, according to Pausanias, moved from an initial, mainland site thought by scholars to have been southwest of modern Urla Iskelesi to an island in the Bay of Smyrna (modern Klazu00fcmen). This place resource represents the later city; see also Klazomenai (earlier).

properties.name: Korou Pedion
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 56 F4 Korou Pedion

properties.name: Korykos M.
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 56 D5 Korykos M.

properties.name: Kryos (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 56 F4 Kryos fl.

properties.name: Latom
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 56 C4 Latom

properties.name: Leleges
properties.description: Aboriginal peoples of the Aegean littoral.

properties.name: Lesbos (island)
properties.description: Lesbos is an island of the northeastern Aegean Sea and was named for the son of Lapithos, the descendant of Deucalion and Helen.

properties.name: Lydia/Maionia (region)
properties.description: Lydia was a region in Western Asia Minor, situation between Ionia on the west, Caria on the south, Phrygia on the east, and Mysia on the north. It was home to an Iron Age kingdom (q.v), and gave its name to a succession of administrative areas of the Roman empire and other states.

properties.name: Lykos (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 56 F4 Lykos fl.

properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 56 D4 Myrmekes

properties.name: Mysia (region)
properties.description: A region of northwestern Asia Minor.

properties.name: Mysios (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 56 F3 Mysios fl.

properties.name: Nakrason (or Nakrasos)
properties.description: An ancient settlement whose precise location is unknown. Modern scholars place it variously at Bakir, Maltepe, or u0130lyaslar in modern Turkey.

properties.name: *Nakrason?/Tibbai?
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 56 F3 *Nakrason?/Tibbai?

properties.name: Caermote Roman fort
properties.description: The earthwork remains of a first century A.D. Roman fort and a possible second century fortlet.

properties.name: Palace of Ardashir
properties.description: A castle built in A.D. 224 by King Ardashir I of the Sassanian Empire, the Palace of Ardashir is located 2 km north of Gor.

properties.name: Villa Hadriani
properties.description: The Villa of Hadrian (Villa Adriana in Italian) is a sprawling archaeological complex at Tivoli, Italy. The villa complex was designed and used by the emperor Hadrian in the second century A.D.

properties.name: Aqua Anio Novus
properties.description: Aqua Anio Novus is an ancient aqueduct supplying the city of Rome. Begun by Caius in A.D. 38, it was completed and dedicated by Claudius in A.D. 52.

properties.name: Aqua Iulia
properties.description: A Roman aqueduct built by Marcus Agrippa in 33 BC and expanded by Augustus between 11 and 4 BC.

properties.name: Villa del Torraccio, Torrenova
properties.description: The Forma Italiae notes the presence of drainage channels, foundations, and a cistern that are taken to be indicative of a Roman villa in the locale known today as Torrenova in the eastern portion of modern Rome.

properties.name: Ponte Ceccara
properties.description: The Ponte Ceccara, also referred to as the ponte di Terra, is a Republican period bridge located on the fosso di Passerano along the Via Praenestina. It is located within the modern comune of Zagarolo, some 30.5 km southeast of the center of Rome.

properties.name: Ponte Amato
properties.description: The bridge known as Ponte Amato carries the Via Praenestina near Gallicano.

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: The Salinae Romanae at Ostia were said to have been established by Ancus Marcius.

properties.name: Aenaria/Pithekoussai (island)
properties.description: Aenaria/Pithekoussai Ins. (modern Ischia) is a volcanic island located in the northern part of the Bay of Naples.

properties.name: Agellum
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 44 E1 Agellum

properties.name: Alfaterni
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 44 G4 Alfaterni

properties.name: Amasenus (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 44 D3 Amasenus fl.

properties.name: Atina
properties.description: Atina was a Samnite hill town with a polygonal masonry fortification wall.

properties.name: Caecubus Ager
properties.description: A tract of Latium that bordered the Gulf of Amyclae, lying in the territory of Fundi.

properties.name: Caedicius? Campus
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 44 E3 Caedicius? Campus

properties.name: Calor (river)
properties.description: A river of Samnium and a major tributary of the Volturno river.

properties.name: Campania
properties.description: Campania was a region of southern Italy.

properties.name: Campanus Ager
properties.description: The Campanus Ager was the region around Capua that the Romans confiscated in 211 B.C. during the Second Punic War.

properties.name: Campus Stellas
properties.description: The name for a region of Campania that adjoined the Ager Falernus.

properties.name: Capreae (island)
properties.description: An island of the Bay of Naples off the Sorrentine Peninsula that has, since the time of the Roman Republic, been a popular seaside resort area. The emperor Tiberius maintained twelve villas on the island.

properties.name: Carecini Infernates
properties.description: Carecini Infernates, one of the four ancient tribes that made up the Samnite population.

properties.name: Carecini Supernates
properties.description: The Carecini Supernates were a tribe of Samnites.

properties.name: Cereatae Marianae
properties.description: Cereatae Marianae, purported to have been the birthplace of Gaius Marius, is thought to have been located where the 13th century abbey church of Casamari now stands (in the modern province of Frosinone, Lazio, Italy).

properties.name: Cumae/Kyme (Campanian)
properties.description: An ancient settlement of Campania, Cumae was the first Greek colony established on the Italian mainland in the eighth century BC.

properties.name: Decennovium
properties.description: Decennovium refers to a 19-mile stretch of the Via Appia from the Forum Appii to Tarracina that continued through the paludes Pontinae.

properties.name: Digentia (river)
properties.description: A stream in the ager Sabinus.

properties.name: Falernus Ager
properties.description: The Ager Falernus comprised the northern portion of Campania from the Massican hills to the Vulturnus river. The area was celebrated for its fertility and, in particular, for its wines.

properties.name: Frentani
properties.description: An Italic people of eastern Italy occupying a territory between the Apennines and the Adriatic seaboard, the Frentani had a close cultural connection with the Samnites.

properties.name: Gianola
properties.description: The site of a villa associated with Lucius Vitruvius Mamurra.

properties.name: Iuvencus (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 44 E2 Iuvencus fl.

properties.name: Latium (region)
properties.description: The territory of the Latins.

properties.name: Latium Adiectum
properties.description: A region of ancient Italy characterized as an area of Latin colonial expansion; also referred to as Latium Novum.

properties.name: Laurinienses
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 44 G4 Laurinienses

properties.name: Lucrinus (lake)
properties.description: A small lake near Lake Avernus.

properties.name: Neratii
properties.description: This site of an imperial villa, dating to the first and second centuries, covers an area of ca. 15,000 sq. m. It is located in the southern portion of the modern civic territory of San Giuliano del Sannio in the Provu00edncia de Campobasso, Italy.

properties.name: Nymphaeus (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 44 C3 Nymphaeus fl.

properties.name: Pentri
properties.description: The Pentri were a major tribe of Oscan-speaking Samnites; their chief center was Bovianum Undecumanorum.

properties.name: Samnite Sanctuary at Pietrabbondante
properties.description: An ancient sanctuary on the slope of Monte Saraceno in the modern Italian comune of Pietrabbondante.

properties.name: Pomptinae Paludes
properties.description: The Pomptinae Paludes (Pontine Marshes) is an area of former marshland in Latium.

properties.name: Pomptinus Ager
properties.description: Pomptinus Ager (Pomptine plain) is a region in Latium lying between Albanus M. and the Tyrrhenian coast.

properties.name: Pontiae (islands)
properties.description: An archipelago in the Tyrrhenian Sea off the west coast of Italy.

properties.name: Puteolanus Sinus/Crater
properties.description: Also called the Bay of Naples, the Puteolanus Sinus is a gulf located on the southwestern coast of Italy. It opens west to the Mediterranean Sea and is bordered on the east by Mt. Vesuvius and the south by the Sorrentine Peninsula.

properties.name: Regio Statana?
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 44 E3 Regio Statana?

properties.name: Samnium (region)
properties.description: Samnium is the Latin name for a region of south and central Italy inhabited by the Samnites. The geographic limits of this region prior to sustained Roman contact are poorly defined. With the Augustan reorganization of Italy, the pre-Roman Samnium is subdivided among three of the Augustan regions.

properties.name: S. Rocco
properties.description: The San Rocco villa was built during the second quarter of the first century B.C. It was initially a simple villa rustica and it was later enlarged substantially.

properties.name: S. Sebastianus
properties.description: San Sebastiano in the territory of Alatri originates in the late fifth century.

properties.name: Sarrastes
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 44 G4 Sarrastes

properties.name: Scatebra (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 44 E2 Scatebra fl.

properties.name: Sirenes/Seirenoussai Inss.
properties.description: Sirenes/Seirenoussai Inss. (modern Le Sirenuse or Li Galli) is an archipelago off the Amalfi Coast of Italy. In Greek mythology, the islands were home to the Sirens who tempted sailors, including Odysseus.

properties.name: Suessula
properties.description: Suessula was an important ancient city of Campania.

properties.name: Taurasinus? Ager
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 44 G3 Taurasinus? Ager

properties.name: Tifernus (river)
properties.description: The Tifernus (modern Biferno) is a river of Molise that flows from near Bojano to the Adriatic Sea.

properties.name: Tifernus M.
properties.description: Tifernus M. (Monti Matese), a mountain chain that straddles Campania and Molise in the central-southern Apennines.

properties.name: Trinius (river)
properties.description: The Trigno river in Molise.

properties.name: The Sanctuary of Vastogirardi
properties.description: A sanctuary of the Pentrian Samnites on the flanks of Monte Capraro, north of the modern Italian village of Vastogirardi.

properties.name: Villa Iovis
properties.description: A 7,000 mu00b2 palatial villa built atop the island of Capreae by the Roman emperor Tiberius.

properties.name: Villa Tiberii
properties.description: A coastal villa at Sperlonga associated with the Roman emperor Tiberius.

properties.name: Volsci
properties.description: The Volsci (Volscians) were an Italic tribe of central Italy during the first millennium B.C. They inhabited parts of southern Latium and were bounded by other tribes, including the Aurunci, Samnites, and Hernici.

properties.name: Volturnus (river)
properties.description: The Volturno river flows 175 km from the Apennines to the Tyrrhenian Sea at Castel Volturno.

properties.name: Apiolae
properties.description: An ancient city of Latium that led the Latin resistance against Tarquinius Priscus.

properties.name: Capitulum Hernicum
properties.description: A Hernican town that still existed in Pliny's time, Capitulum Hernicum received colonists under both Sulla and Iulius Caesar.

properties.name: Cominium Ocritum
properties.description: Cominium Ocritum was a Samnite stronghold captured in 291 BC by Quintus Fabius Maximus Gurges.

properties.name: Lanuenses
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 44 unlocated Lanuenses

properties.name: Pedum
properties.description: Pedum was an ancient city of Latium that was part of the Latin League. Located between Tibur and Praeneste, its precise location is now unknown. Some suggest that modern Gallicano is the site of the ancient city.

properties.name: Romulea
properties.description: Now unlocated, Romulea was captured by the Romans during the Third Samnite War.

properties.name: Tifata (Latium)
properties.description: Tifata is a site in Latium listed as defunct by the elder Pliny. Palmer notes that Festus (43 L) raises the question of an identically named Roman curia.

properties.name: Verrugo
properties.description: Verrugo was a Volscian settlement at the borders of Latium. Its location is now uncertain.

properties.name: Acalander (river)
properties.description: Acalander fl.. a river of Lucania emptying into the Gulf of Tarentum.

properties.name: Ad Duodecimum
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 45 H4 Ad Duodecimum

properties.name: Alburnus M.
properties.description: Alburnus M. is a mountain of Lucania near the river Silarus.

properties.name: Apuli
properties.description: The Apuli were an ancient tribe of southeastern Italy.

properties.name: Apulia
properties.description: Apulia is a region of the south-eastern Italian peninsula.

properties.name: Aquilo (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 45 C1 Aquilo fl.

properties.name: Atinas Campus
properties.description: A toponym applied by the elder Pliny to an area of Lucania.

properties.name: Aufidus (river)
properties.description: The Aufidus is the longest of the rivers in Apulia.

properties.name: Bradanus (river)
properties.description: A river of Lucania which flows into the Gulf of Tarentum.

properties.name: Calabria
properties.description: Ancient Calabria comprised the southern part of Apulia and the Salento peninsula.

properties.name: Chones
properties.description: Chones, an ancient Lucanian tribe.

properties.name: Hirpini
properties.description: The Hirpini were an ancient Samnite people of central Italy.

properties.name: Iapyges
properties.description: The Iapyges were a pre-Roman, Indo-European people that inhabited Apulia in southeastern Italy.

properties.name: Messapii
properties.description: The Messapii were an ancient Indo-European people occupying the Salento peninsula in southeast Italy.

properties.name: Metapontum
properties.description: An important city of Magna Graecia, Metapontum was located on the Gulf of Tarentum. The Achaeans were responsible for its foundation, perhaps as early as the eighth century B.C.

properties.name: Moio della Civitella
properties.description: A fortified outpost (phrourion) of the city of Velia/Elea.

properties.name: Paestanus Sinus
properties.description: A gulf of the Tyrrhenian Sea.

properties.name: Pagus Vetanus
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 45 G3 Pagus Vetanus

properties.name: Peucetii
properties.description: The Peucetii were an ancient tribe of Apulia in southern Italy.

properties.name: Poediculi
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 45 E3 Poediculi

properties.name: Regio Auffeeiana
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 45 A3 Regio Auffeeiana

properties.name: Sallentini
properties.description: Sallentini were a tribe of an ancient Apulia, the 'heel' of the booth of the Italian peninsula. They spoke the Messapian language.

properties.name: Saltus Carminianensis?
properties.description: The Saltus Carminianensis? is a large imperial property of northern Apulia mentioned in the Notitia Dignitatum Occidentis.

properties.name: Tomb of Priscilla
properties.description: A Roman tomb along the Via Appia that belonged to one Priscilla, wife of Titus Flavius Abascanto, a freedman of the emperor Domitian.

properties.name: Gallo-Roman Structure at Moissac
properties.description: A Gallo-Roman structure including hypocaust and other remains of a bath, located beneath the later Church of Saint Martin in modern Moissac, France. The bath may have belonged to a villa of the fourth-fifth centuries CE.

properties.name: Puentecillas
properties.description: A bridge of the sixteenth century that rests on Roman foundations.

properties.name: Shrine of Venus Cloacina
properties.description: The Sacrum Cloacina was a small shrine dedicated to Venus Cloacina, patron divinity of the sewer, and was located near the Tabernae novae in the Forum Romanum. The foundation of the sacellum is extant while images of its likely elevation are found on Roman coins.

properties.name: Sardurihinili
properties.description: An Urartian fortress constructed in the eighth century BCE and destroyed in the seventh century BCE.

properties.name: Sebasteion
properties.description: The Sebasteion at Aphrodisias was a temple complex dedicated to Aphrodite and the Iulio-Claudian emperors that was financed by local patrons. It was built between ca. AD 20 and 60. The complex was excavated in 1979-81.

properties.name: Fortified Port Settlement on Cape St. Athanasius
properties.description: An ancient settlement with fortifications and port facilities located on the modern Cape St. Athanasius near Byala in Bulgaria.

properties.name: Khirbat Iskandar
properties.description: A fortified site on the banks of the Wadi al-Wala in Jordan inhabited in the Early Bronze IV period.

properties.name: Cadira del Bisbe
properties.description: A terraced pre-Roman settlement located in Premiu00e0 de Dalt. The site flourished between the fifth and third centuries B.C. and was abandoned by the first century B.C

properties.name: Nuraghe Toscono
properties.description: A single tower nuraghe standing ca. 7.25 meters.

properties.name: Santa Maria dell'Orto
properties.description: The church of Santa Maria dell'Orto is a Roman Catholic church located in Rome's Trastevere district. Its foundation is traced to 508.

properties.name: Guadarmes (river)
properties.description: Today is known as the Guadalmez, the Guadarmes is a river located in the south of the province of Ciudad Real, Spain.

properties.name: Matrera castle
properties.description: Castillo de Matrera is a Spanish castle that originally dates to the ninth century and is located in the northeast of the province of Cu00e1diz. It belonged to the kingdom of Alfonso X (in the thirteenth century). Today it is located in the municipality of Villamartu00edn.

properties.name: Panjakent
properties.description: The easternmost city of Sogdiana, inhabited from the fifth-ninth centuries CE.

properties.name: Ishkhani (monastery)

properties.name: Kars

properties.name: Toprak Kala
properties.description: The site of a walled Chorasmian city, inhabited from the first to sixth centuries CE, located approximately 40 kilometers north of the Afrighid capital city of Kath.

properties.name: Aeolis
properties.description: Sometimes defined as covering the entrance of the Hellespont to the mouth of the Hermus river, Aeolis was region centered on the North West coast of Asia Minor and some islands, notably Lesbos. Herodotus lists the eleven ancient cities of Aeolis as Cyme, Lerisae, Neon Teichos, Temnos, Cilla, Notion, Aegiroessa, Pitane, Aegaeae, Myrina, and Gryneia. He also claims that Smyrna was once an Aeolian city, but was taken by the Ionians at an unspecified date.

properties.name: Eupatoria/Magnopolis
properties.description: Eupatoria/Magnopolis was a Hellenistic city of Pontus in Asia Minor founded initially by Mithridates VI Eupator in the valley of Phanaroea, near the confluence of the Lykos and Iris rivers. Cnaeus Pompeius re-founded the city as Magnopolis.

properties.description: Mortuary temple of the Nineteenth Dynasty in the Theban Necropolis.

properties.name: Nuraghe Nuracale
properties.description: A quadrilobate nuragic complex located in the territory of Scano di Montiferro.

properties.name: Casa della statuetta indiana
properties.description: The so-called Casa della statuetta indiana (I.8.5) lies on the Via dell'Abbondanza. Excavated between 1930 and 1935, it was named for the fine ivory statuette (thought by some to depict Lakshmi) found inside. The house has a slightly irregular floor plan with some rooms added to the structure from adjacent properties.

properties.name: Taberna Pomaria di Felix
properties.description: A fruit shop in Pompeii (I, 8, 1) with an entrance on to the Via dell'Abbondanza.

properties.name: Pistrinum of Betitius Placidus
properties.description: A small shop located in Regio I of Pompeii (I, 8, 7).

properties.name: Aisepos fl.
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 56 E2 Aisepos fl.

properties.name: Ezida
properties.description: The temple of the god Marduk as Tutu, later of the god Nabu00fb, at Borsippa. The Sumerian ceremonial name Ezida means True House.

properties.name: Eniggidrukalamasuma
properties.description: The temple of the god Nabu00fb of the u1e2baru00fb as at Borsippa. The Sumerian ceremonial name Eniggidrukalamasuma means House which Bestows the Scepter of the Land.

properties.name: Ekiu0161nugal
properties.description: The temple of the moon god Nanna/Suen/Su00een at Ur from the third to first millennium B.C. Over the course of its long history, it was rebuilt (and expanded) numerous times. A few of its more famous builders were Naru0101m-Su00een of Agade, Ur-Nammu of Ur, and Nebuchadnezzar II of Babylon.

properties.description: A place from the TAVO Index

properties.description: A place from the TAVO Index

properties.name: Munzur Dau011flaru0131
properties.description: A place from the TAVO Index

properties.name: Tilmen Hu00f6yu00fck
properties.description: A bronze age settlement in the Islahiye valley of modern Turkey where habitation seems to have begun as early as the Late Chalcolithic.

properties.name: Torre del Papito
properties.description: A Medieval tower in Rome's Largo Argentina.

properties.name: Casa dei Crescenzi
properties.description: A structure in Rome built between 1040 and 1065 by one Niccolu00f2, son of Crescenzio and Teodora, in order to control the Ponte Emilio, on whose transit the family charged a toll. The building incorporates ancient spolia.

properties.name: Caesareum of Alexandria
properties.description: Hellenistic temple constructed by Cleopatra VII and dedicated to Julius Caesar, and later rededicated by Augustus to himself. In 13 BCE Augustus relocated two obelisks from Heliopolis to the site. The temple was converted to a Christian church in the mid-4th century.

properties.name: Cima tumulus
properties.description: A rock-cut Etruscan tomb dating to the second half of the seventh century B.C.

properties.name: Tumulo del tesoro
properties.description: An Etruscan tumulus of the seventh century B.C.

properties.name: Bilske Horodyshche
properties.description: Archaeological site near the village of Bilsk in Ukraine; possibly the site of Gelonos, identified by Herodotus as the capital city of the Budini.

properties.name: Bestansur
properties.description: The archaeological site at Bestansur is in the Shahrizor Plain in the foothills of the Central Zagros mountains in modern Iraq. The tell, which lies just east and south of the modern village, shows evidence for extensive Early Neolithic occupation as well as later Neo-Assyrian and Sasanian activity.

properties.name: Cencelle
properties.description: A Medieval settlement that, according to textual sources, was founded in 854 by Pope Leo IV in order to provide a more secure position for the citizens of Centumcellae (Civitavecchia). Situated along the ancient VIa Aurelia, Cencelle occupies a defensible hill positioned between the Melledra and Mignone rivers. The site chosen for the Medieval city likely occupies the former site of an Etruscan oppidum.

properties.name: Pisciarelli necropolis
properties.description: An Etruscan necropolis with tombs dated to the archaic period located near modern Civitavecchia in Italy.

properties.name: Nerik
properties.description: Nerik was a Bronze Age, Hittite settlement. It is likely to be identified with the Oymaau011fau00e7 Hu00f6yu00fck in northern Turkey.

properties.name: Via Popilia (in Aemilia)
properties.description: A road from Ariminum up the Adriatic Coast toward what is now Venice.

properties.name: tribus Sergia
properties.description: An older rural tribe of ancient Rome.

properties.name: Litana Silva
properties.description: The Litana Silva was a forest located in Gallia Cispadana in the territory of the Boii. It was the site of the defeat of the Roman consul L. Postumius Albinus in 216 BC. Its precise location is uncertain, but it probably lay somewhere in the flat land south of the Po river in Italy.

properties.name: Osrhoene
properties.description: Osrhoene was a Syriac-speaking kingdom of upper Mesopotamia that enjoyed semi-autonomy to complete independence from 132 BC to AD 244.
