properties.name: Basilica di Santa Balbina all'Aventino
properties.description: The basilica of Santa Balbina is a paleo-Christian basilica in Rome, located on the little Aventine.

properties.name: Domus Cilonis
properties.description: The house of Lucius Fabius Cilo, praefectus urbi in 203, consul in 193 and 204, and a close friend of the emperor Septimius Severus. The house was a gift of the Severans and appears on the Severan marble plan. Its site is now occupied by the basilica of Santa Balbina on the little Aventine.

properties.name: Caelius Mons
properties.description: The Caelian Hill in Rome.

properties.name: al-u1e24illa
properties.description: A place from the TAVO Index

properties.name: Ka'ba-ye Zartosht
properties.description: A stone monument located in the Naqsh-e Rustam compound.

properties.name: La Granu00e8de, Millau
properties.description: An oppidum located on the headland of the Larzac, overlooking the valley of the Tarn river.

properties.name: Enunmah
properties.description: The u1e2bilu1e63u-building of the goddess Ningal inside the Egiu0161nugal temple at Ur. The Sumerian ceremonial name Enunmah means House of the Exalted Prince.

properties.name: Egipar
properties.description: The Giparu-House at Ur was the temple of the high-priestess of the moon-god.

properties.name: Temple of Apollo at Hierapolis
properties.description: The Temple of Apollo at Hierapolis, built during the Hellenistic period.

properties.name: Bakla Tepe
properties.description: A site located on what is now an island in Tahtalu0131 Baraju0131 near Izmir. The site shows signs of habitation from the Chalcolithic period to the Late Bronze Age, as well as a later Romano-Byzantine settlement. The plain surrounding the site was flooded by the Tahtalu0131 Dam in 1999.

properties.name: Horomos
properties.description: Armenian monastery constructed in the 10th century CE.

properties.name: Zaralulu
properties.description: Evidence for second millennium B.C. copper working were discovered at the site.

properties.name: La Peyrelongue
properties.description: A massive, square tower of the Roman period.

properties.name: Pimentel, Necropoli di S'Acqua Salida e di Corongiu
properties.description: A necropolis of the second millennium B.C.

properties.name: Noddule nuragic complex
properties.description: A multi-period settlement site with occupation stretching from ca. 4000 B.C. to the fourth century A.D.

properties.name: Mullissu Gate
properties.description: The Mullissu Gate, which was given the Akkadian ceremonial name Mullissu-muddiu0161at-u1e2biu1e63bi (The Goddess Mullissu Is the One Who Restores Abundance), is the fourth of the eight city gates of Du016br-u0160arruku012bn (Fort Sargon) listed by Sargon II (r. 721u2013705 BC) in inscriptions recording the construction of his new capital. This gate is the second of the north-facing entrances to the city.

properties.name: Anu Gate
properties.description: The Anu Gate, which was given the Akkadian ceremonial name Anu-muu0161allim-epu0161u0113t-qu0101tu012bya (The God Anu Is the One Who Makes My Undertakings Successful), is the fifth of the eight city gates of Du016br-u0160arruku012bn (Fort Sargon) listed by Sargon II (r. 721u2013705 BC) in inscriptions recording the construction of his new capital. This gate is the first of the west-facing entrances to the city.

properties.name: tribus Aemilia

properties.name: Qasr al-Mshatta
properties.description: An Umayyad palace in Jordan, the construction of Qasr al-Mshatta is thought to have been started under Caliph Walid II around A.D. 743-44, just before the Abbassid Revolution, and it was never completed.

properties.name: Axaraffe de Seuilla
properties.description: A region located in the suburbs of Sevilla that belonged to the kingdom of Alfonso X. It is now known as El Aljarafe.

properties.name: North Palace at Deir el-Ballas
properties.description: Royal palace in the Upper Nile in use from the Second Intermediate Palace to the early New Kingdom.

properties.name: Nabulu
properties.description: A town mentioned in Neo-Assyrian sources that is now identified as modern Girnavaz Hu00f6yu00fck. Nabulu was a Late Bronze Age and an Iron Age settlement located north of Nusaybin.

properties.name: Qaziqulu necropolis
properties.description: Burial ground near the village of Qaziqulu in Azerbaijan's Tovuz district. The site contains a number of burials dated from the 10th-7th centuries BCE. The site was inundated during the construction of the Tovuzchay reservoir in 2016.

properties.name: Villa Carmiano
properties.description: A villa rustica of about 400 square meters that was discovered at Stabiae in 1963. The site was reinterred in 1998.

properties.name: Yererouk
properties.description: Archaeological site in western Armenia containing the remains of a basilica originally constructed in the 4th-6th centuries CE.

properties.name: Trajanic harbor
properties.description: The hexagonal Trajanic harbor basin at Portus was built between 100 and 112. Its maximum diameter is approximately 716 meters.

properties.name: Amaghu Noravank
properties.description: Armenian monastery constructed in the 13th-14th centuries CE, located 3km east of the modern village of Amaghu.

properties.name: Ptghnavank
properties.description: Church building in the modern village of Ptghni, Kotayk province, Armenia, dated to the 6th-7th centuries CE.

properties.name: Basentello (river)
properties.description: A river of southern Italy, Basentello flows near the border between Apulia and Basilicata. It flows from its source near Palazzo San Gervasio to Bradano.

properties.name: Qasr Al-Kharanah
properties.description: Early Islamic structure in Eastern Jordan, likely constructed prior to the 8th century CE. Though its outward appearance suggests a castle, it does not seem to have had any military function, and the original purpose of the structure is not known.

properties.name: Porta all'Arco
properties.description: The Porta all'Arco is a city gate of Volterra. Later incorporated into Medieval walls, the gate originates in the fourth and third centuries B.C.

properties.name: Roman Odeion at Corinth
properties.description: The Roman Odeion at Corinth dates to the first century A.D.

properties.name: Macedonian palace at Pella
properties.description: The Macedonian palace at Pella, now only partially excavated, occupied an area of perhaps 60,000 square meters. The palace consisted of up to seven large architectural groupings.

properties.name: Rousolakos
properties.description: A Minoan site in eastern Crete.

properties.name: Bodhgaya
properties.description: A town in India traditionally identified as the place in which Gautama Buddha attained enlightenment. One of the four main Buddhist pilgrimage sites, it is home to the Mahabodhi Temple, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

properties.name: Icknield Street
properties.description: Icknield Street was a road of Roman Britain running from Fosse Way to Templeborough.

properties.name: Clepsydra of the Oropos Amphiareion
properties.description: The Oropos Amphiareion clepsydra is a hydraulic inflow clock serving the Sanctuary of Amphiaraus. Situated on the southeast bank of the sacred spring of Amphiaraus, this inflow hydraulic clock dates to the 4th century BCE.

properties.name: Tall-e Geser
properties.description: Village in Iran inhabited since the 6th millennium BCE.

properties.name: Semien Mountains
properties.description: A mountain range of northern Ethiopia first mentioned in the Monumentum Adulitanum and now a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

properties.name: Great Temple of Petra
properties.description: The Great Temple of Petra is one of the major archaeological and architectural components of central Petra. It is located to the south of the Colonnaded Street and southeast of the Temenos Gate and covers 7560 square meters.

properties.name: Uu015faklu0131 Hu00f6yu00fck
properties.description: A Bronze and Iron Age site in Yozgat province, Turkey, tentatively identified as the Hittite town of Zippalanda (u00c7adu0131r Hu00f6yu00fck is another candidate for the location of Zippalanda).

properties.name: u00c7adu0131r Hu00f6yu00fck

properties.name: Mersin-Yumuktepe
properties.description: A tell known today as Yumuktepe is located at modern Mersin in Turkey. Excavations there, beginning in the 20th century, have provided evidence for continuous and/or successive human settlement beginning in the Neolithic period. Scholars believe that the names Ingiru00e2 (found in Akkadian sources) and Anchiale(ia) (found in Greco-Roman sources) are to be associated with the site.

properties.name: Kundu/Kyinda
properties.description: Kundu is mentioned in Akkadian royal inscriptions of the seventh-century-BC Assyrian king Esarhaddon. In Classical times, Strabo describes Kyinda as a fortress where Macedonian kings deposited treasure. Eumenes reportedly captured the treasure when he revolted against Antigonus. The site is now unlocated.

properties.name: Amphipolis/Tourmeda/Nikatoris?

properties.name: London Mithraeum
properties.description: A temple sacred to Mithras in Londinium that was discovered in 1954. The visible remains of the temple do not sit on the original site, but have been reassembled at Temple Court, Queen Victoria Street, London.

properties.name: Casa dei Grifi
properties.description: A late Republican domus of the Palatine Hill that was later consumed by the substructures of the Domitianic wing of the Flavian palace. The Casa dei Grifi preserves important wall paintings that are transitional from the First to the Second Pompeian style. Giacomo Boni discovered the domus in 1912.

properties.name: Catacombs of Domitilla
properties.description: A Christian catacomb located on the via Ardeatina.

properties.name: u0130u015fhan

properties.name: Via Aemilia
properties.description: The Via Aemilia was a major Roman trunk road of northern Italy and connected Placentia and Ariminum. Its construction began in 187 BC under M. Aemilius Lepidus.

properties.name: Circus Flaminius
properties.description: Located in the southern Campus Martius, the Circus Flaminius is a large area built by C. Flaminius Nepos in 221 B.C. Various games, including the ludi plebeii, ludi Taurii, ludi saeculares, were celebrated here. The circus was also a place of popular assembly.

properties.name: So-called Theatre 2
properties.description: The ruins of an ancient theatre in Cyrene, known as Theatre 2.

properties.name: Lutibu
properties.description: Lutibu is a fortified city in Sam'alla that is mentioned in royal inscriptions of the Assyrian king Shalmaneser III (r. 858-824 BC). It is often identified with Saku00e7agu00f6zu00fc (Coba Hu00f6yu00fck), which is ca. 20 km northeast of Sam'al (Zincirli Hu00f6yu00fck).

properties.name: Uru0161u/Waru0161uwa
properties.description: Uru0161u/Waru0161uwa was an Assyrian trading colony (ku0101rum) located on the route between Au0161u0161ur and Kaneu0161. This important city is attested in Eblaite and Sumerian sources, including an inscription of Gudea of Lagau0161 that describes the rebuilding of the temple of the god Ningirsu at Girsu; numerous Old Assyrian and Old Babylonian texts; and Hittite sources, for example, the annals of king Hattusili I, a literary composition generally referred to as u2018The Siege of Uru0161u,u2019 a treaty between the Hittite king and Sunassura of Kizzuwatna, and a land grant to a nobleman (Sahurunuwa).

properties.name: Camarina
properties.description: Camarina was founded by Syracuse in 599 B.C., but subsequently destroyed in 552 B.C. The city was re-founded by Gela in 461 B.C. Carthage razed the site in 405 B.C., but Timoleon restored it in 339 B.C. From the late third century B.C. the town fell under Roman administration.

properties.description: A place from the TAVO Index

properties.name: City Wall of Dura-Europos
properties.description: The fortified wall encircling the city of Dura-Europos built primarily of locally-quarried ashlar limestone blocks. Built ca. 150 BCE, the walls were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.

properties.name: Eastern Outer Wall of Babylon
properties.description: The Neo-Babylonian ruler Nabopolassar (r. 625u2013605 BC) started planning and constructing an outer wall around the eastern side of Babylon. This massive mudbrick brick wall, together with its protective quay wall and a wide moat, remained unfinished at the time of Nabopolassaru2019s death. His son and successor Nebuchadnezzar II (r. 604u2013562 BC) finished the work started by his father. Traces of Babylonu2019s once-impressive eastern outer wall are still visible today.

properties.name: Karacamirli Tepe 5
properties.description: Necropolis in western Azerbaijan containing 46 burials dated to the Late Bronze Age/early Iron Age, the Late Antique period, and the 14th century CE.

properties.name: Via Severiana
properties.description: The Via Severiana was a coastal route running from Ostia to Terracina, a distance of ca. 80 Roman miles.

properties.name: Torre dei Capocci
properties.description: The Torre dei Capocci, together with the Torre dei Graziani, was built in the twelfth century by the Arcioni family as a monumentalized entrance to the Esquiline.

properties.name: Torre dei Graziani
properties.description: The Torre dei Graziani is a twelfth-century tower on the Esquiline Hill in Rome.

properties.name: Vega del Mar
properties.description: A paleochristian basilica.

properties.name: So-called House of the Mosaic Columns
properties.description: Suburban villa outside the Herculaneum gate in Pompeii

properties.name: Telul eth-Thalathat
properties.description: A site in northern Iraq (approximately 40 km west of Mosul) comprising a cluster of four large tells and several smaller low tells. The site was occupied in the Ubaid, Uruk, and Middle Assyrian periods.

properties.name: Ninurta-muku012bn-temmu0113n-u0101liu0161u-ana-labu0101r-u016bmu0113-ru016bqu016bti
properties.description: The Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721u2013705 BC) surrounded his new capital Du016br-u0160arruku012bn (Fort Sargon) with a rectangular-shaped, 16,280-cubit-long inner and outer city wall. The name of the outer/lower city wall (u0161alu1e2bu00fb) was Ninurta-muku012bn-temmu0113n-u0101liu0161u-ana-labu0101r-u016bmu0113-ru016bqu016bti (The God Ninurta Is the One Who Establishes the Foundation of His City for (All) Days to Come) according to some Akkadian royal inscriptions, but Ninurta-muku012bn-temmu0113n-aduu0161u0161i-ana-labu0101r-u016bmu0113-ru016bqu016bti (The God Ninurta Is the One Who Establishes the Foundation of the Wall for (All) Days to Come) according to other texts written in the name of Sargon II.

properties.name: Adad Gate
properties.description: The Adad Gate, which was given the Akkadian ceremonial name Adad-muku012bn-u1e2begallu012bya (The God Adad Is the One Who Establishes My Prosperity), is the second of the eight city gates of Du016br-u0160arruku012bn (Fort Sargon) listed by Sargon II (r. 721u2013705 BC) in inscriptions recording the construction of his new capital. This gate is the second of the eastward-facing entrances to the city.

properties.name: Iu0161tar Gate
properties.description: The Iu0161tar Gate, which was given the Akkadian ceremonial name Iu0161tar-muu0161ammeu1e2bat-niu0161u012bu0161u (The Goddess Iu0161tar Is the One Who Makes Its People Flourish), is the sixth of the eight city gates of Du016br-u0160arruku012bn (Fort Sargon) listed by Sargon II (r. 721u2013705 BC) in inscriptions recording the construction of his new capital. This gate is the second of the west-facing entrances to the city, but its precise location is uncertain.

properties.name: Sebetti temple (Khorsabad)
properties.description: A temple dedicated to the Sebetti, the divine seven, was excavated by Iraqi archaeologists in 1957. This temple at Du016br-u0160arruku012bn (modern Khorsabad) is located just west of the citadel, near Citadel Gate A and City Gate 7.

properties.name: Gosbecks
properties.description: The Gosbecks farm site is the location of a Romano-Celtic temple. The shrine measures 100 meters square and a pre-Roman enclosure lies within the later temenos. The pre-Roman site was likely sacred to the war-god Camulos. Camulos was later synchronized with the Roman god Mars, although evidence for the worship of Mercury was also discovered at the site.

properties.name: Dendra
properties.description: Bronze Age cemetery near the Mycenean settlement of Midea.

properties.name: Forum Traiani
properties.description: Imperial forum constructed at Rome under Trajan between 105-112 CE.

properties.name: Bath-Gymnasium Complex at Sardis
properties.description: Bath/gymnasium complex containing a palaestra and a synagogue that was developed in the 3rd century CE.

properties.name: Tomb of Seuthes III
properties.description: An elaborate tomb located near Kazanlak, Bulgaria. The Tomb of Seuthes III, who was King of the Odrysian Kingdom from ca. 331 to ca. 300 BC, is found in the Valley of the Thracian Rulers.

properties.name: Sanctuary of Artemis Limnatis at Messene
properties.description: A sanctuary on the slopes of Mount Ithome and within the city walls of ancient Messene in the Peloponnese. It was developed beginning in the 4th-3rd centuries BCE.

properties.name: S. Pietro ad centum muros
properties.description: On the hill of Grignano, located on the outskirts of Montebuono, the remains of a Roman villa were first excavated in the nineteenth century in the area of the church of S. Pietro ad centum muros. Excavation in the 1990s revealed further villa remains beneath the church and in the vicinity of its cemetery. Epigraphic evidence attesting to the consulship of M. Vipsanius Agrippa was discovered immured in the church (CIL 9.4677 and 9.4779).

properties.name: Madinat Hamad 2 Burial Mound Field (Karzakkan)
properties.description: A necropolis of the early Dilmun culture, dating to the second millennium B.C.

properties.name: San Nicola di Trullas
properties.description: A Medieval church on the island of Sardinia that is dated to 1133.

properties.name: Avenches Roman amphitheater
properties.description: The Avenches Roman amphitheater.

properties.name: Mogil'nik Mau012dtan
properties.description: Bronze Age burial ground in east-central Kazakhstan.

properties.name: Mochlos (island)
properties.description: Mochlos is an island in the Gulf of Mirabello, although in antiquity it was likely connected to the Cretan mainland. The island is the site of an ancient Minoan settlement.

properties.name: Faroe Islands
properties.description: An archipelago made up of 18 islands situated between the Norwegian Sea and the North Atlantic Ocean.

properties.name: Rio Maior
properties.description: A Roman villa.

properties.name: Solenyu012d Dol
properties.description: Burial complex in the southern Ural Mountains region containing a number of Late Antique burials.

properties.name: Villa di Loron, Cervar
properties.description: A site in Istria that served as a major source of olive oil in the 1st-4th centuries CE. The site is associated with the production of Dressel 6B amphorae.

properties.name: Theater of Ephesus
properties.description: The Theater of Ephesus sits at the foot of the Panayir mountains. It could host up to 25,000 spectators.

properties.name: New Nisa
properties.description: The tell site of New Nisa is part of the Parthian fortress of Nisa, designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

properties.name: Old Nisa
properties.description: The tell of Old Nisa is part of the Parthian fortress of Nisa, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

properties.name: Au0161nakkum
properties.description: Town in the Khabur River basin in Northern Syria, now known as Chagar Bazar. First settled in the Neolithic Period, the town appears to have been abandoned during the Early Bronze Age. It was resettled in the Early Dynastic period, becoming an administrative center of the Old Assyrian Empire.

properties.name: Multangular Tower
properties.description: The Multangular Tower at York once stood at the west corner of the Roman legionary fortress.

properties.name: Bolu02b9shou012d Salbykskiu012d kurgan
properties.description: The Great Salbyk Mound is the largest burial mound in the Khakassia region of Russia. The mastaba-like tomb, associated with the Bronze Age Tagar culture, was constructed in the 7th century BCE, and may have had an astronomical function.

properties.name: Underground Shrine (Paestum)
properties.description: A small, underground tomb-like structure located in the agora of Paestum, thought to be either a shrine or a heroon.

This major archaeological site from which archaeologists recovered over 23,000 Greco-Buddhist sculptures in the twentieth century is thought to have been destroyed by ongoing military conflict in Afghanistan.

properties.name: Kobedyle
properties.description: A settlement mentioned in ancient sources that cannot be precisely located today. It was probably located in the area of modern Turkey called Buru00e7ak Ovasu0131 (ancient Kastolou Pedion), northeast of Philadelpheia (modern Alau015fehir).

properties.name: Ea-Damkina temple (Kalhu)
properties.description: When Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud) became the principal administrative center of the Assyrian Empire in the ninth century BC, king Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883u2013859 BC) built (or rebuilt) numerous temples. One of those was dedicated to the god Ea and the goddess Damkina. Although its location is not known, the Ea-Damkina temple at Kalhu is thought to have been situated within the Ninurta temple complex, in the northwest corner of the citadel.

properties.name: Jemdet Nasr
properties.description: An ancient site in Iraq's Babil Governorate (Iraq) that lends its name to the Jemdet Nasr period (ca. 3100u20132900 B.C.).

properties.name: Forum of Roman Corinth
properties.description: The Roman forum of ancient Corinth.

properties.name: Roman theater of Lokroi Epizephyrioi
properties.description: A Roman theater of the first century B.C. built on the site of the fourth century B.C. Greek theater.

properties.name: Roman theater at Volaterrae
properties.description: The Roman theater of Volaterrae was built during the during the Augustan period under the consulship of Aulus Caecina Severus.

properties.name: Avitta Bibba amphitheater
properties.description: A Roman amphitheater located in the modern Siliana Governorate of Tunisia.

properties.name: Emah
properties.description: The temple of the goddess Ninmah/Bu0113let-ilu012b, Emah (u201cExalated Houseu201d), was located in the Ka-dingirra district (modern Kasr) of Babylon. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, this was one of four temples in that part of the city, which was located in the northern part of the eastern half of Babylon. Emah was rebuilt by the Assyrian king Ashurbanipal (r. 668u2013ca. 631 BC) and the Babylonian king Nebuchadnezzar II (r. 604u2013562 BC).

properties.name: Temple of Al-Lat at Palmyra
properties.description: A temple sacred to the goddess Al-Lat in Palmyra. The earliest shrine on the site was constructed in the mid-first century BCE, and was greatly expanded during the second century CE. The temple was closed and its altar destroyed during the 380s CE.

properties.name: Mura Messapiche
properties.description: Well-preserved remains of the ashlar fortification walls at Manduria.

properties.name: Falerna
properties.description: A rural tribe of Rome, which was established in 318 B.C.

properties.name: Tor di Mezzavia di Frascati
properties.description: The Tor di Mezzavia is a Medieval tower located along the modern Via Tuscolana, marking the midway point between Rome and Frascati.

properties.name: Kara-Tepe
properties.description: A Buddhist monastery constructed near the city of Tarmita/Termez in the early second century CE.

properties.name: Roman amphitheater of Venusia
properties.description: A Roman amphitheater dating to the first and second centuries.

properties.name: Gravelly Guy
properties.description: A settlement near modern Stanton Harcourt, Oxfordshire, England, occupied from the late Neolithic through the Roman periods.

properties.name: Ananauri Big Kurgan No. 3
properties.description: Bronze Age burial site of the Alazani-Bedeni culture near the Alazani River in eastern Georgia. The site is dated to the first half of the 24th century BCE.

properties.name: Rabau00e7al Roman villa
properties.description: A fourth-century AD Roman villa located in Rabau00e7al, Portugal, near the site of Conimbriga.

properties.name: Mycenae
properties.description: Mycenae was an ancient settlement of the Argolid, with the earliest occupation evident ca. 2900 B.C. As the eponymous site of the Mycenaean culture of the Aegean Bronze Age, the site flourished as a fortified citadel during the mid to late second millennium B.C. In the first millennium B.C., the site experienced a revival of fortunes, although by Strabo's time the settlement had vanished.

properties.name: Patra(e)
properties.description: Patra(e) (modern Patras) is an important ancient center with settlement beginning in the Late Helladic period. Patras played a leading role in the foundation of the second Achaean League and was the site of a Roman colony after 146 BC.

properties.name: Peloponnesus/Peloponnesos/Peloponnese
properties.description: The large peninsula protuding into the Mediterranean Sea that constitutes the southern part of Greece. It is largely separated from mainland Greece on the north by the Corinthian Gulf, joining it only in the northeast via the narrow Isthmus of Corinth.

properties.name: Tainaron (settlement)
properties.description: An ancient settlement, located near the tip of a southern peninsula of the Peloponnese, known also by the name Tainaron in antiquity (modern Cape Matapon in Greece).

properties.name: Tainaron Pr.
properties.description: Tainaron Pr. (Cape Matapan) is the southernmost point of mainland Greece.

properties.name: Tenea
properties.description: Tenea was an ancient city of the Corinthia famous for its sanctuary of Apollo. Scholars have long believed it is to be located in the area of modern Chiliomodi in Greece. Recent scientific excavations have identified the general extent of a large, multi-period cemetery zone to the east and south of the modern town, as well as an extensive bath complex of Roman date.

properties.name: Thyrea(tis)

properties.name: Tiryns
properties.description: A fortified Mycenaean center in the Argolid that flourished between 1400 and 1200 B.C.

properties.name: Touthoa (river)
properties.description: An ancient river of the northwest Peloponnese, described by Pausanias as flowing into the Ladon at the border of Thelpusian and Heraian territory (i.e., prior to the Ladon's confluence with the Alpheios).

properties.name: Triphylia
properties.description: Triphylia was a region of the western Peloponnese located north of the Alpheius river and south of the Neda river.

properties.name: Dema wall
properties.description: The so-called Dema wall was a built fortification of ancient Attica that was intended to a close a gap between between Aigaleos and Parnes. The wall's course originally ran more than 4 km.

properties.name: La Hoya, Alava
properties.description: A prehistoric Iberian settlement of the Iron Age.

properties.name: Antinoeion at Hadrian's Villa
properties.description: A sacred precinct at the western end of Villa Hadriani, comprising two temples at opposite (north and south) ends of a plaza or garden, and (on the western edge of this complex) a small colonnaded hemicycle. Here, Hadrian may have planned to build a large, semi-circular temple-tomb for Antinous, in place of which his successors built the colonnaded hemicycle.

properties.name: Public Bath of Pella
properties.description: The Public Bath at Pella is a bathing complex constructed and continuously renovated between the 4th and the 1st centuries BCE.

properties.name: Polygonal wall of Signia
properties.description: The circuit wall of ancient Signia realized in polygonal masonry.

properties.name: Sobek temple, Qau015fr Qu0101ru016bn
properties.description: A Ptolemaic temple to the god Sobek.

properties.name: Northwest Palace at Kalhu
properties.description: An impressive and ornately-decorated palace constructed at Kalu1e2bu (modern Nimrud, biblical Calah) by the ninth-century-BC Assyrian ruler Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883u2013859 BC), likely completed between 865 and 869 BC. This multi-winged palatial complex served as the primary residence and chief administrative center of the Assyrian Empire until Sargon II (r. 721u2013705 BC) moved the imperial capital to Du016br-u0160arruku012bn in 706 BC. The Northwest Palace, the name given to it by its excavators (since it was built in the northwestern part of Kalu1e2buu2019s citadel), remained in use until the very end of the Assyrian Empire (612 BC). The southern half of the building also functioned as the burial place of prominent royal women, including Mullissu-mukanniu0161at-Ninua, the wife of Ashurnasirpal and the mother of Shalmaneser III.

properties.name: Roman civil amphitheater at Carnuntum
properties.description: Located outside the city wall, the Roman amphitheater at Carnuntum dates to the later second century. It could accommodate some 13,000 spectators. The amphitheater likely went out of use by the fourth century.

properties.name: Qatna
properties.description: A city in western Syria first settled in the Early Bronze Age III (ca. 2700-2600 BCE). In the Middle Bronze Age (2000-1600 BCE), it became a major trading center and the capital of a regional kingdom. In the Late Bronze Age Qatna the city became a vassal of first the Mitanni Kingdom, then the Neo-Hittite Empire and Egypt. The city's acropolis was abandoned in the Late Bronze Age I, though the surrounding area remained inhabited. It was resettled in the 10th century BCE as part of the Aramaean kingdom of Hamath, but was sacked by the army of Sargon II in 720 and ultimately abandoned in the 6th century BCE.

properties.name: Roman amphitheater at Trier
properties.description: The Roman amphitheater at Trier dates to the reign of Antoninus Pius and was renovated under Constantius Chlorus. The arena measures ca. 71 x 47.5 meters.

properties.name: Porta Nigra
properties.description: The so-called Porta Nigra is a surviving Roman city gate that dates to ca. A.D. 186-200. It was enlisted as part of the Roman Monuments, Cathedral of St. Peter and Church of Our Lady in Trier UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1986.

properties.name: Royal Palace of Qatna
properties.description: A large palace constructed in about 1600 BCE in Qatna, an important Bronze Age city in Syria.

properties.name: Royal Hypogeum at Qatna
properties.description: Tomb VI at Qatna, known as the Royal Hypogeum, is a tomb complex located approximately 12 meters below the Royal Palace of Qatna. The tomb consists of a long corridor and 4 burial chambers, and contained approximately 20 burials.

properties.name: Kontopigado, Alimos
properties.description: An Early Helladic workshop site.

properties.name: Acropolis of Circeii
properties.description: The polygonal masonry walls of the Acropolis of Circeii enclose an area of approximately two hectares. The walls likely date to the middle republican period.

properties.name: Tuvixeddu Punic necropolis
properties.description: A Punic necropolis near Caralis in Sardinia.

properties.name: Santa Maria in Cosmedin
properties.description: A minor basilica church in Rome, Italy. Tradition holds that the church was founded in the sixth century to serve the Greek community at Rome. The beginnings of the present edifice lie in the eighth century.

properties.name: San Giorgio in Velabro
properties.description: A church dedicated to St. George located in Rome's Velabrum. Legend connects the church's location with the spot where the Roman she wolf found the abandoned twins, Romulus and Remus.

properties.name: Graeco-Roman theater at Isthmia
properties.description: A theater founded ca. 390 B.C. with subsequent Hellenistic and Roman renovations.

properties.name: Temple of Demeter
properties.description: A Doric temple ascribed to Demeter with origins in the fourth century B.C.

properties.name: Malthi chamber tomb
properties.description: A Mycenaean chamber tomb at Malthi, located near the Greek village of Vasiliko.

properties.name: Chydas? (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 47 F2 Chydas? fl.

properties.name: Pantelleria (island)
properties.description: An island in the Strait of Sicily with human occupation dating back at least 35,000 years, Pantelleria has evidence for Bronze Age, Punic, Roman, Medieval, and modern phases. The Romans first acquired the island in 255 B.C. They called it Cossyra.

properties.name: Crimisus (river)
properties.description: A river of western Sicily.

properties.name: Cyclopum Scopuli Tres
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 47 G3 Cyclopum Scopuli Tres

properties.name: Damyrias (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 47 G4 Damyrias fl.

properties.name: Daskon Akron
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 47 G4 Daskon Akron

properties.name: Eleutheros (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 47 C3 Eleutheros fl.

properties.name: Elymi
properties.description: The Elymians were an indigenous people inhabiting western Sicily during the Bronze Age and the first millennium BC.

properties.name: Epipolai
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 47 G4 Epipolai

properties.name: Erineos (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 47 G5 Erineos fl.

properties.name: Euryelos
properties.description: A fortress built by Dionysius the Elder 9 km west of Syracuse, in the modern hamlet of Belvedere (Sicily).

properties.name: Halaesa
properties.description: Halaesa is located on the north coast of Sicily between between Kalakta and Kephaloidion. The city was founded in 403 B.C. by Archonides of Herbita. The city sided with Rome during the First Punic War and was made libera et immunis. By the Augustan period it had become a municipium.

properties.name: Halykos (river)
properties.description: The Halykos (modern Platani) is the fifth longest river in Sicily.

properties.name: Santa Cristina
properties.description: A nuragic sanctuary centered on a sacred well that was in use from ca. 1200 to 700 BC.

properties.name: Golata Niva
properties.description: An archaeological site near the village of Sinemorets. The site of a Thracian aristocratic woman's home, dated to the third to second centuries BCE.

properties.name: Tel Kabri
properties.description: Archaeological site near the modern settlement of Kabri in northern Israel. The site shows signs of occupation from the late Neolithic period and the Early (Ia-II) and Middle (IIA-B) Bronze Ages. The site was an important city in the Middle Bronze Age, rapidly expanding during the 18th century BCE with the construction of a rampart and one of the largest known Canaanite palaces. It was abandoned by about 1500 BCE, and later habitations (in the Iron Age, Hellenistic, and Ottoman periods) were of smaller scale.

properties.name: Temple of Artemis at Sardis
properties.description: A large temple dedicated to Artemis at the city of Sardis in western Asia Minor. A sanctuary to Artemis was constructed on the site during the Persian Era (ca. 547-334 BCE), and construction on a new temple on the site began during the third century BCE. The temple was never fully completed. A small church was built on part of the site in the 5th century CE, but the structure declined from the 7th century onwards, and many of its stones were reused or burned.

properties.name: Milecastle 37 (Housesteads)
properties.description: One of the milecastles along Hadrian's Wall, approximately 400 meters to the west of Housesteads Roman fort (Vercovicium)

properties.name: Tel Jatt
properties.description: A site between the Sharon Plain and the Samarian Hills on which the modern town of Jatt is built. The site contains numerous Bronze Age burials and signs of habitation as late as the Bronze Age. The site has been proposed as a possible location for the town of Ginti-kirmil mentioned in the Amarna letters.

properties.name: Mausoleum of Helena
properties.description: An ancient tomb located on the ancient Via Labicana (now along the Via Casilina) that was built by Constantine I and used as the tomb for his mother, Helena.

properties.name: Church of Saint Martin at Moissac
properties.description: A Christian church built, at least in part, atop the ruins of a Gallo-Roman building that include a hypocaust.

properties.name: Porta Trasimena
properties.description: The Porta Trasimena or Arco di San Berni is a third century B.C. gate in the Etruscan wall of Perusia.

properties.name: Suburbium Toletanum
properties.description: The location of the Late Roman and Visigothic suburbium beyond the Roman circus. Transition from suburban villas to a large-scale Visigothic expansion, which included various churches and the Praetorium, or Royal Palace. Destroyed during the ninth century. Excavations carried out in the early 2000s.

properties.name: Stadium-garden at Hadrian's Villa
properties.description: A garden at the Villa Hadriani imitating the shape of a stadium, situated between the Three Exedras' Hall (to the west) and the Winter Palace (to the east), with a semi-circular nymphaeum at its southern end.

properties.name: Fundus Albianus
properties.description: An estate located in the Pagus Ambitrebius mentioned on the Tabula alimentaria Traianea.

properties.name: Madhukeshwara temple
properties.description: A Shiva temple at Banavasi in India whose foundation may date as early as the 7th century CE.

properties.name: Valdonega Roman villa
properties.description: The Roman villa of Valdonega near Verona dates to the first century A.D.

properties.name: Church of St. George
properties.description: One of of a group of eleven rock-hewn monolithic churches located in Lalibela, a city in the Amhara Region of Ethiopia. The church likely dates to the twelfth or thirteenth century.

properties.name: Ekklesiasterion/Theater at Metapontum
properties.description: A building complex located in the city's agora, the Ekklesiasterion/Theater is dated ca. 625-300 B.C.

properties.name: Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi
properties.description: A papal basilica begun ca. AD 1228.

properties.name: Roman amphitheater at Luna
properties.description: The Roman amphitheater at Luna was built in the second century, perhaps during the Antonine period.

properties.name: Roman amphitheater at Mactaris
properties.description: The Roman amphitheater at Mactaris dates to the second century.

properties.name: Mastaba of Ptahshepses at Abusir
properties.description: The mastaba-style tomb of Ptahshepses, vizier to the Fifth Dynasty Pharaoh Nyuserre Ini. Following the intial elite burials in the Old Kingdom, the mastaba became a funerary site for new burials during the Late Period.

properties.name: Mycenaean cemetery at Achaia Clauss
properties.description: A Mycenaean-era cemetery located near the modern-day Achaia Clauss vineyard southeast of Patras, Greece.

properties.name: Ganeshwar
properties.description: Chalcolithic settlement in modern Rajasthan, India. The pre-Harappan settlement, located near copper mines and inhabited during the 4th-3rd millennia BCE, is one of two type-sites of the Ganeshwar-Jodhpura Cultural Complex.

properties.name: Stadium
properties.description: The stadium at Aphrodisias dates to the later first century A.D. and is thought to be part of a comprehensive program of monumental construction undertaken at the site. The stadium's form is unusual and scholars assign it to a category referred to as u03c3u03c4u03acu03b4u03b9u03bfu03bd u1f00u03bcu03c6u03b9u03b8u03adu03b1u03c4u03c1u03bfu03bd (an amphitheatral stadium).

properties.description: Gadeira/Gades/Col. Augusta Gaditana (modern Cadiz, Spain) is an ancient city of Spain and one of the oldest continuously occupied cities of Europe. Its origins may be Phoenician (Gadir (Phoenician: u05d2u05d3u05e8)).

properties.name: Tagus (river)

properties.name: Tartessos
properties.description: Tartessos was a harbor city and surrounding region located on the southern coast of the Iberian peninsula at the mouth of the Guadalquivir River.

properties.name: Torre Aguila

properties.name: Tru00f3ia

properties.name: Baliares/Gymnesiae Inss. (Maior et Minor)
properties.description: Baliares/Gymnesiae Inss. (Maior et Minor) (The Balearic Islands) is an island group of the western Mediterranean Sea, located to the east of the Iberian peninsula. In modern geographical terms, the four largest islands of the group are Majorca, Minorca, Ibiza, and Formentera, but the latter two are also part of the Pityussae island group of antiquity.

properties.name: Palace of Nebuchadnezzar II
properties.description: The Neo-Babylonian king Nebuchadnezzar II constructed for himself a large and ornately decorated palace, the ruins of which are still visible today. This extensive architectural complex was located in the Kadingirra district of Babylon, which is situated just south of the Ishtar Gate, east of the processional street Ay-ibu016br-u0161abu00fb, north of the Lu012bbil-hengalla canal, and west of the Euphrates River. Several Akkadian inscriptions of Nebuchadnezzar II record the construction of this building.

properties.name: Sippar-Amnanum
properties.description: Sippar-Amnanum, located at modern Tell ed-Der, was an ancient city of the Old Babylonian period and the sister city of Sippar.

properties.name: Archaic agora of Thasos
properties.description: The agora of the ancient city. The site was located near the center of the city's shoreline and was surrounded by stoas and public buildings.

properties.name: Ermin Street
properties.description: A branch Roman road (Margary 41) running from Calleva Atrebatum (modern Silchester) to the legionary fortress at Col. Glevum (Gloucester). Not to be confused with the major north-south road named Ermine Street (Margary 2).

properties.name: Trakhtemyrivsu02b9ke horodyshche
properties.description: A Scythian-period (seventh-sixth centuries BCE) hillfort site on the right bank of the Dnieper River, consisting of a large fortified territory (Velyki Valky) surrounding a smaller acropolis (Mali Valky).

properties.name: Knowth
properties.description: Knowth is a Neolithic passage grave of Bru00fa na Bu00f3inne in the valley of the River Boyne in Ireland. The site, covering almost a hectare, is comprised of a central, large mound (Site 1) and 17 smaller satellite tombs.

properties.name: Dowth
properties.description: Dowth is a Neolithic passage tomb in the Boyne Valley, County Meath, Ireland.

properties.name: Castra of Drobeta
properties.description: A Roman castrum dating to the reign of Trajan located on the Danube, at Turnu-Severin, Romania.

properties.name: Church of Saint Eusebius (Ronciglione)
properties.description: A paleochristian sanctuary located along the Via Francigena.

properties.name: Villa del Cimitero Flaminio

properties.name: Porta Fontinalis
properties.description: No longer extant, the Porta Fontinalis is only known via textual and epigraphic references. Presumed to be a gate of the Servian Wall, the Porta Fontinalis lay in the Campus Martius, west of the via Lata. It may have been the original point of issuance for the Republican roads known as the Via Flaminia and the Via Salaria.

properties.name: Duurlig Nars
properties.description: Xiongnu tomb site near the modern village of Bayan-Adarga, Khentii, Mongolia. The site contains burials dated from the 4th century BCE to the 2nd century CE.

properties.name: Gonur Tepe
properties.description: A city in the Murghab River delta inhabited in the third-second millennia BCE. Gonur Tepe is located ca. 60 km north of Mary, Turkmenistan.

properties.name: Huzirina
properties.description: The ancient Huzirina, modern Sultantepe, is a Late Neo-Assyrian archeological site, now in u015eanlu0131urfa Province, Turkey.

properties.name: Tell Leilan
properties.description: Tell Leilan is situated near the Wadi Jarrah, in the Khabur River basin in Al-Hasakah Governorate, northeastern Syria. The ancient names of the site are Shekhna and Shubat-Enlil.

properties.name: Bahra 1
properties.description: Archaeological site north of Kuwait Bay containing an Ubaid Period settlement.

properties.name: Tall Bazi
properties.description: Archaeological site on the eastern bank of the Euphrates in northern Syria. The site contains a town dated to the Early Bronze Age III-IVA (mid-3rd millennium BCE), as well as a Roman sanctuary used only briefly from about the late 1st-late 2nd century CE. The western part of the site was flooded by the construction of the Tischrin Dam in 1999. Tall Bazi and the nearby site of Banat have been tentatively identified as the city of Armi/Armium mentioned in texts from Ebla.

properties.name: Ghubayru0101
properties.description: Town in southern Iran built on a burial site used in the 3rd-4th millennia BCE and the Sasanian period. The town on the site was inhabited from from the 10th-14th century.

properties.name: Kamyana Mohyla
properties.description: A stone barrow site near the Molochna River comprising over 50 grottoes and caves, many containing petroglyphs dating from the Mesolithic age through the second millennium BCE, with additional graffiti dated as late as the twelfth century CE.

properties.name: So-called House of Hesychios
properties.description: A Roman peristyle house located in Cyrene.

properties.name: The Forum of Corporations
properties.description: A key commercial center occupying the quadriporticus of the theater of Ostia, the Forum of Corporations dates initially to the Augustan period but is substantially rebuilt in the second century.

properties.name: Greek theater at Alabanda
properties.description: The Greek theater at Alabanda dates to the Hellenistic period.

properties.name: Temple of Apollo at Delphi
properties.description: The Temple of Apollo situated in the center of the oracular sanctuary of that god at Delphi.

properties.name: Sanctuary of Apollo at Cyrene
properties.description: A sanctuary at Cyrene dedicated to Apollo Karneios. The sanctuary was in use between the seventh century BC and the second century AD, and included shrines to other gods, including Artemis and Isis.

properties.name: L-Shaped Palace at Gla
properties.description: A complex of multifunctional rooms at Gla with two connected wings that extend from a right angle to form two u02bamegaronsu02ba that lacked hearths and throne rooms. The palace was built around 1300 BCE.

properties.name: City wall of Pompeii
properties.description: The city walls of Pompeii surround the ancient urban center and have several architectural phases.

properties.name: Byllis
properties.description: A Hellenistic and Roman site located on the right bank of the Aous river with a defensive circuit of ca. 2 km.

properties.name: Chaonia
properties.description: A district of Epirus inhabited by the Chaonians, a Greek tribe.

properties.description: Herakleia or Herakleia Lynkestis was an ancient city of Macedonia founded by Philip II of Macedon in the middle of the fourth century B.C.

properties.name: Illyricum
properties.description: Illyricum was a Roman province that existed from 167 BC until AD 10.

properties.description: Pirustae were a Pannonian Illyrian tribe that lived in modern Montenegro.

properties.description: Skardon M., the u0160ar Mountains, is a mountain range in the Balkans that extends from Kosovo to northeastern Albania.

properties.description: Taulantioi, a group of ancient Illyrian tribes.

properties.name: Amphax(it)is
properties.description: The western maritime district of Mygdonia in ancient Macedonia.

properties.name: Tomb of Quintus Sulpicius Maximus
properties.description: The tomb of the boy poet Quintus Sulpicius Maximus on the Via Salaria in Rome. He died in 94 CE, aged just 11 years.

properties.name: Via Ardeatina
properties.description: The Via Ardeatina connected Rome and Ardea.

properties.name: Dede Harabeleri
properties.description: Late Antique rural settlement located in Gaziantep Province, Turkey, less than 2km southeast of the tell at Tilbau015far Kalesi. Salvage excavations were carried out on the site in 2016-2018 prior to the construction of the Dou011fanpu0131nar Dam.

properties.name: Kom el-Ahmer
properties.description: Archaeological site in the province of Beheira in the Western Delta, inhabited from the Roman through the Early Islamic periods. Along with the nearby site Kom Wasit, it has been identified as a possible location of Metelis, the capital of the Metelite Nome.

properties.name: Skara Brae
properties.description: Skara Brae is a stone-built Neolithic settlement located on the west coast of Mainland, the largest island in the Orkney archipelago. Comprised of eight clustered houses, the village was occupied from roughly 3180 to 2500 BC.

properties.name: Yassu0131 Ada (island)
properties.description: An island bordering the Chuka Channel in the southeastern Aegean sea; two shipwreck sites (dating to the fourth and seventh centuries A.D.) are located off its southern coast.

properties.name: Thermes gallo-romains, Pithiviers-le-Vieil
properties.description: A Gallo-Roman bath complex at Pithiviers-le-Vieil.

properties.name: Madinat Hamad 3 Burial Mound Field (Dar Kulayb)
properties.description: A necropolis of the early Dilmun culture, dating to the second millennium B.C.

properties.name: Roman bridge, Cu00f3rdoba
properties.description: A first century Roman bridge over the Guadalquivir river.

properties.name: Castellet de Bernabu00e9
properties.description: An Iberian town dating between the fifth century B.C. and the third century A.D. It has a quasi-orthogonal plan and cover approximately 1,000 square meters.

properties.name: Amphitheater of Thizica
properties.description: The small Roman amphitheater of Thizica.

properties.name: Pau0161ime
properties.description: Pau0161ime is an ancient settlement located at Tall Abu016b u0160u012bjah, an archaeological site in the Maysan province of southeastern Iraq, close to the Iranian border. The site was inhabited perhaps already from the fourth millennium BCE, and particularly in the third and early second millennium BCE. The name Pau0161ime appears in an Old Akkadian inscription discovered at the site in the course of excavations by the Iraq State Board of Antiquities and Heritage in 2007. The inscription was dedicated to the god u0160uda, indicating that a temple devoted to this deity may have been located at Pau0161ime.

properties.name: Via Praenestina
properties.description: A consular road running from Rome to Praeneste.

properties.name: Palaiokastro
properties.description: Settlement/fortress descibed by Stu00e4hlin (1924, 224-225); Bu00e9quignon (1937, 322-324; Fig. 16).

properties.name: Basilica
properties.description: An important civic building in Pompeii and an early example of the building type, built between ca. 120 and 78 B.C. (VIII, 1, 1).

properties.name: Badnigalbilukurau0161uu0161u
properties.description: Ninevehu2019s main (or great) inner wall was called Badnigalbilukurau0161uu0161u (Wall Whose Brilliance Overwhelms Enemies). It was constructed by the Neo-Assyrian king Sennacherib after he moved the Assyrian capital to Nineveh. Badnigalbilukurau0161uu0161uu2019s superstructure was reportedly raised to a height of 200 courses of brick. The visible remains of the twelve-kilometer-long wall and some of its gates are still visible today.

properties.name: Eu0161ahulezenzagmukam
properties.description: Around 690 B.C., the Neo-Assyrian king Sennacherib started construction on a New Yearu2019s Temple for Ninevehu2019s tutelary deity Iu0161tar. Eu0161ahulezenzagmukam, whose Sumerian ceremonial name means House of Joy and Gladness for the Festival of the Beginning of the Year was never completed and work on it appears to have come to a complete stop ca. 688 B.C., when Sennacherib decided to rebuild the Aku012btu Temple at Ashur instead.

properties.name: Iu0361Asinovskiu012d III Kurgan
properties.description: Bronze age burial site near the banks of the Seversky Donets.

properties.name: Vignale
properties.description: A Roman villa, mansio, and Late Antique settlement along the Via Aemilia Scauri.

properties.name: Fort Shalmaneser
properties.description: The ninth-century-BC Assyrian king Shalmaneser III (r. 858u2013824 BC) constructed an impressive palatial complex in the southeastern corner of the city Kalhu (biblical Calah). This armory, which the seventh-century-BC ruler Esarhaddon (r. 680u2013669 BC) referred to as an u0113kal mu0101u0161arti (u2018review palaceu2019), was completed ca. 846 BC. Fort Shalmaneser, the name of building dubbed by its excavators, remained in use until the very end of the Assyrian Empire (612 BC), although its importance was significantly diminished after the Assyrian court moved away from Kalhu at the end of the eighth century BC, first to Du016br-u0160arruku012bn and then to Nineveh.

properties.name: Pont du Diable (Cu00e9ret)
properties.description: A Medieval bridge spanning the Tech river that dates between 1321 and 1341.

properties.name: Tech (river)
properties.description: The Tech river flows some 84 km from its source is the Parcigoule Valley to the Mediterranean Sea.

properties.name: Jrvezh
properties.description: Village east of Yerevan in Armenia. The town, which has been settled since at least the 5th century CE, contains a 7th-century chapel.

properties.name: Palatium Sessorianum
properties.description: Palatium Sessorianum is of unknown origins. It was situated at the extreme south-east of Region V and it adjoined the amphitheatrum Castrense. It pre-dated the Aurelian wall. The portions of the complex within the line of the walls was an imperial residence by the time of Constantine.

properties.name: Curia Iulia
properties.description: The building of the Curia Julia was begun by Julius Caesar and completed by Augustus in 29 BCE. It replaced the former senate house, the Curia Hostilia.

properties.name: Via Egnatia
properties.description: The Via Egnatia was a Roman road begun in the second century BC that crossed the Roman provinces of Illyricum, Macedonia, and Thrace.

properties.name: Temple of Jupiter Heliopolitanus
properties.description: The Temple of Jupiter Heliopolitanus at Baalbek is considered the largest temple of the Roman world. It served as an oracular shrine.

properties.name: Temple of Bacchus
properties.description: Part of the complex of Roman temples at Baalbek, the Temple of Bacchus is one of the best-preserved temples of the Roman world. It is conventionally dated to the second century CE.

properties.name: Al-'Assu0101su012bf
properties.description: Necropolis on the West Bank of the Nile near Thebes containing tombs from the 18th, 25th, and 26th dynasties.

properties.name: Nymphaeum divi Alexandri
properties.description: A monumental nymphaeum on the Esquiline Hill dating to the Severan period; commonly known as Trofei di Mario. The complex is located at a fork between the Via Tiburtina and the Via Labicana.

properties.name: Gallicia
properties.description: A region of northwest Spain that belonged to the kingdom of Alfonso X. It is now known as Galicia.

properties.name: tribus Clustumina
properties.description: The tribus Clustumina (or Crustumina) was a rural tribe of Rome which was established in 495 B.C.

properties.name: Stele of Horemheb at Karnak
properties.description: Horemheb was the last pharaoh of the 18th Dynasty of Egypt. The deeds of his career were recorded on a stele that was mountaed at the foot of the Tenth Pylon of the Karnak temple.

properties.name: Telesterion
properties.description: The Telesterion (ca. 435 - 421 B.C.) was a sacred hall at Eleusis used for the annual initiation ceremonies for the cult of Demeter and Persephone known as the Eleusinian Mysteries.

properties.name: Koumasa prepalatial cemetery
properties.description: A prepalatial cemetery on the island of Crete that includes three tholos tombs and one rectangular tomb.

properties.name: Santa Maria in Legarano
properties.description: Site of a large Roman villa, the remains of which were incorporated into the church of Santa Maria in Legarano. The early phases of the villa likely date to the early imperial period. At some point the villa became an Imperial property as it was donated to Pope Sylvester by Constantine.

properties.name: Arzawa
properties.description: A kingdom or federation in western Anatolia, whose exact location(s) and extent are matters of scholarly debate. The presence and nature of Arzawa is gleaned primarily from Hittite royal annals and diplomatic texts of the LBA, as well as the two letters from Amarna between Amenhotep III and the king of Arzawa. These texts, however, do not reveal the temporal span of Arzawa, and should be treated as snapshots in time. Arzawa reached its greatest prominence in the middle of the fourteenth century BCE, but had been reduced to a rump state by the end of the century. The remaining territory formed the core of the kingdom of Lydia.

properties.name: Didi Liakhvi
properties.description: The Greater Liakhvi River, a tributary of the Kura River in the South Ossetia region of the Republic of Georgia.

properties.name: Via Sublacensis
properties.description: The Via Sublacensis was built in order to connect the Villa Neronis (Nero's villa at Sublaqueum) to Rome. It split from the Via Valeria near Varia.

properties.name: Via Herculia
properties.description: A Roman road known through epigraphic attestations, the Via Herculia connected Aquilonia and Aequum Tuticum.

properties.name: Forum Romanum
properties.description: The ancient Roman forum.

properties.name: Arch of Augustus (Susa)
properties.description: An arch dedicated to Augustus at Susa in the late first century BC that records the renewed alliance between the princeps and Marcus Julius Cottius.

properties.name: Jerash Hippodrome
properties.description: The Jerash Hippodrome dates after the middle of the second century. While among the smallest of the attested examples of Roman period hippodromes, it numbers among the best preserved.

properties.name: Roman amphitheater at Veleia
properties.description: The Roman amphitheater of Roman Veleia.

properties.name: Roman amphitheater at Spoletium
properties.description: The remains of the early Imperial amphitheater were discovered within the Caserma Minervio during the early nineteenth century.

properties.name: Roman amphitheater at Verona
properties.description: The Roman amphitheater at Verona dates to ca. A.D. 30.

properties.name: San Martino ai Monti
properties.description: San Martino ai Monti is a minor basilica in Rome. The basilica was founded on a site donated by Equitius during the reign of Pope St. Sylvester I in the fourth century.

properties.name: Theater at the Sanctuary of Asklepios, Epidauros
properties.description: The Greek theater in the Sanctuary of Asklepios at Epidauros, renowned for its acoustics

properties.name: Battery at Caer Mote
properties.description: An earthwork enclosure that is of indeterminate date, although it is possibly Roman.

properties.name: Seyitu00f6mer Hu00f6yu00fck
properties.description: Settlement in west-central Anatolia inhabited in the Early-Middle Bronze Age (3000-1700 BCE) and again during the Achaemind and Roman periods (500 BCE-395 CE).

properties.name: Sirkeli Hu00f6yu00fck
properties.description: Settlement in Cilicia inhabited from the Chalcolithic Period (ca. 5000 BCE) to the Hellenistic/early Roman period (100 CE).

properties.name: Roman amphitheater at Scythopolis/Nysa
properties.description: The Roman amphitheater at Scythopolis/Nysa.

properties.name: Forum of Scylletium/Scolacium
properties.description: The Roman Forum of Scylletium/Scolacium.

properties.name: Roman amphitheater at Scylletium/Scolacium
properties.description: The Roman amphitheater at Scylletium/Scolacium.

properties.name: Grutenhu00e4uschen
properties.description: The Grutenhu00e4uschen is a Roman funereal temple of the third or fourth century A.D. It has been reconstructed on site.

properties.name: Ninfa
properties.description: Ninfa is now a garden landscape covering more than 100 hectares in the territory of Cisterna di Latina. In archaeological terms, this landscape includes many remains stretching from protohistory to the Middle Ages.

properties.name: Au015fau011fu0131 Pu0131nar
properties.description: A Neolithic site in Eastern Thrace near the town of Ku0131rklareli.

properties.name: Hirbemerdon Tepe
properties.description: A settlement in the upper Tigris River Valley inhabited from the Chalcolithic period through the Iron Age.

properties.name: Tell al-Fakhar
properties.description: Tell al-Fakhar is located in northeastern Iraq. Excavations between 1967 and 1969 two occupation phases dating to the Mitanni/Kassite and Neo-Assyrian periods.

properties.name: Mineral Water Hospital site
properties.description: Remains of a large building discovered in Aquae Sulis. The site now lies on the grounds of the Royal National Hospital for Rheumatic Diseases.

properties.name: Casa del pomarius Felix
properties.description: This house (I.8.2) opens onto the Via dell'Abbondanza and is connected to the taberna at I.8.1 and the shop at I.8.3. It was named the Casa del pomarius Felix from electoral programmata painted on its facade. It has a typical atrium-peristyle plan.

properties.name: Corinth Theater
properties.description: The origins of the theater at Corinth lie in the fifth century B.C. The complex was further expanded during the Hellenistic period. An elaborate renovation during the reign of Hadrian further improved the complex and added a new orchestra and scaenae frons.

properties.name: Nanstallon
properties.description: A small Roman fort.

properties.name: Flavian Amphitheater at Puteoli
properties.description: The Flavian Amphitheater at Puteoli is an amphitheater constructed in the port town of Puteoli under the Flavian dynasty around 80 CE.

properties.description: Lake Vegoritida, once known as Lake Ostrovo, is a large natural lake located in western Macedonia, northern Greece.

properties.name: Emar
properties.description: An important Bronze Age trading center in northern Syria. The site is known today as Tell Meskene.

properties.name: Tempio di Venere, Baiae
properties.description: The so-called Tempio di Venere is likely part of a bathing complex dating to the reign of Hadrian. The surviving structure has an octagonal plan.

properties.name: Limantepe
properties.description: The site of a Bronze Age port settlement near Urla, Turkey.

properties.name: Aula Palatina
properties.description: The Aula Palatina is a Roman Imperial Basilica of the emperor Constantine (German: Konstantinbasilika) located at Trier, Germany. It was built ca. A.D. 310 as part of a Roman palace complex.

properties.name: Triopium
properties.description: Sanctuary of Apollo Triopios, known as the Triopion, in the territory of Knidos, was the federal sanctuary of the Dorian hexapolis.

properties.name: Galatas
properties.description: A Minoan palatial center on Crete dated ca. 1700-1600 BC that was discovered in the 1990s.

properties.name: Alalau1e2b
properties.description: A major Late Bronze Age city in the Amuq River Valley, inhabited during the Second Millennium BCE until about the 12th century BCE.

properties.name: Kabnak
properties.description: An important town of the Middle Elamite period discovered at the archaeological site of Haft Tepe in southwestern Iran. The site was an important center of the Elamite kingdom in the 15th century BCE, and also shows signs of inhabitation from the Parthian to the Early Islamic periods.

properties.name: Shurdhah (modern island)
properties.description: An island in northern Albania, created in modern times when surrounding land was flooded by the creation of a reservoir. It is the site of the llyrian settlement of Sarda.

properties.name: Tappino (river)
properties.description: The Tappino river is located in the modern Molise region of Italy.

properties.name: Mersea Island
properties.description: An island located in the Blackwater and Colne estuaries to the south-east of Colchester.

properties.name: Domus dei Coiedii
properties.description: The so-called Domus dei Coiedii is a domus located at Suasa. It dates to the first century B.C.

properties.name: Chatal Hu00f6yu00fck (Amuq)
properties.description: Mound site in the Amuq Plain inhabited from the late 4th millennium BCE-mid-1st millennium BCE. In the Late Bronze Age Chatal Hu00f6yu00fck was the site of a sizeable town with connections to the Hittite Empire. In the Iron Age the town was within the sphere of the Syro-Hittite state of Unqi, based at Tell Tayinat/Kinaliya. The town gradually declined, but remained inhabited without interruption until at least the fifth century BCE.

properties.name: Tholos at the Sanctuary of Asklepios, Epidauros
properties.description: The Tholos, a circular structure in the Sanctuary of Asklepios at Epidaurus, was constructed beginning between 365-360 BCE. The Tholos was designed by Polykleitos the Younger and features Doric architecture as well as a constructed labyrinth beneath the floor of the structure.

properties.name: Roman aqueduct, Spello
properties.description: An aqueduct carrying water to Spello from the hills below Collepino.

properties.name: Almo (river)
properties.description: A small river of the Ager Romanus that once joined the Tiber just below the walls of Rome. Almo, the eldest son of Tyrrhus, who is one of the heroes in Virgil's Aeneid, shares the river's name.

properties.name: City wall of Ameria
properties.description: The polygonal masonry circuit wall of ancient Ameria.

properties.name: Carrowkeel Megalithic Cemetery
properties.description: A Neolithic cemetery dated to 3400 to 3100 BC. Fourteen passage tombs have been identified.

properties.name: Tibradden Chambered Cairn
properties.description: A prehistoric cairn located atop Tibradden Mountain.

properties.name: Via Domitiana
properties.description: A Roman road of Campania built during the reign of Domitian.

properties.name: Santa Maria Antiqua
properties.description: A fifth-century A.D. Christian church built in the Forum Romanum at the foot of the Palatine Hill.

properties.name: Jebel Khalid
properties.description: Hellenistic settlement constructed in the early 3rd century BCE and abandoned in the 70s BCE. Part of the site seems to have been used later as a Roman camp or fort.

properties.name: Acropolis palace at Jebel Khalid
properties.description: Hellenistic palace at the city of Jebel Khalid on the west bank of the Euphrates.

properties.name: Char Bakr
properties.description: Necropolis of the Ju016bybu0101ri shaikhs located approximately 5 km west of Bukhara. The complex was constructed during the 16th century around the tomb of the scholar Emu0101m Abu Bakr Sau02bfd.

properties.name: Via Sebaste: Apollonia u2194 Antiochia u2194 Neapolis
properties.description: A road network in Pisidia originally built by the governor Cornutus Aquila, beginning ca. 6 BC.

properties.name: Circus of Maxentius
properties.description: The Circus of Maxentius is part of a complex of buildings built by emperor Maxentius on the Via Appia between A.D. 306 and 312.

properties.name: Roman baths of Taormina
properties.description: The Roman baths of Taormina are built atop a public building of the Hellenistic period. The Roman baths originally fronted on the forum and were expanded in the second century.

properties.name: Temple of Amenhotep II
properties.description: Amenhotep II built a temple at Giza that he dedicated to the god Horemakhet, a sun-god identified with the Great Sphinx. It lies northeast of the Sphinx itself.

properties.name: Yeu015filova Hu00f6yu00fck
properties.description: A prehistoric settlement in Bornova, Turkey, that represents the earliest known settlement in the area of u0130zmir. The site was occupied ca. 6500 to 4000 B.C.

properties.name: Seleucid Empire
properties.description: The Seleucid Empire was a Hellenistic kingdom, founded by Seleucus I Nicator, and ruled by the Seleucid dynasty from 312 to 63 BCE. At its height it stretched from the Aegean Sea to northern India, but it steadily lost territory and prestige. The remnants of the kingdom were eventually incorporated into Roman territory as the province of Syria in 64 BCE.

properties.name: tribus Quirina

properties.name: Mokarta
properties.description: A Bronze Age settlement located near Salemi, Sicily. The site has multiple settlement phases, including the Medival ruins referred to as the Castello di Mokarta. A combination of excavation and geophysical prospection has revealed the remains of Bronze Age settlement atop the plateau as well as evidence for outlying necropoleis.

properties.name: Stone of the Pregnant Woman
properties.description: The Stone of the Pregnant Woman in Baalbek, Lebanon is one of the largest monoliths ever quarried.

properties.name: Temple of Athena Nike

properties.name: Mesopotamia (region)
properties.description: An important region surrounding the Tigrisu2013Euphrates river system, in the northern part of the Fertile Crescent, roughly corresponding to most of modern Iraq and Kuwait, eastern Syria, and Southeastern Turkey. Mesopotamia was a critical part of many empires and kingdoms, including the Sumerians, Akkadians, Assyrians, Babylonians, the Achaemenids, Alexander the Great, and the Seleucids. It was also a site of intense conflict between the Roman, Parthian, and Sassanid Empires until the 7th century Muslim conquest.

properties.name: Moxoena
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 89 E2 Moxoena

properties.name: *Mouzoura
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 89 B1 *Mouzoura

properties.name: Mygdonia
properties.description: A plain in Mesopotamia surrounding Nisibis. Alexander the Great settled Macedonian veterans here.

properties.name: Nicephorion (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 89 D2 Nicephorion fl.

properties.name: Nineveh/Ninos
properties.description: This important Mesopotamian city flanks the eastern edge of the Tigris flood plain, opposite modern Mosul, of which it is now a suburb. From the third millennium B.C. onwards, Nineveh was the most important religious center of the goddess Iu0161tar in the area that would become the Assyrian heartland. Starting in the Middle Assyrian period, the city came under the authority of the kings of Assyria, who often sponsored large-scale building activities there. However, it was not until 704 B.C. that Nineveh became the administrative capital of Assyria, when the Neo-Assyrian king Sennacherib moved the royal family and court there and transformed the city into a thriving imperial metropolis. Nineveh remained Assyriau2019s capital until 612 B.C., when it was captured and destroyed by a Babylonian-Median collation led by Nabopolassar and Cyaxares. The visible remains of the (7th-century) Assyrian city include the citadel mound Kuyunjik, the smaller mound of Nebi Yunus, and the twelve-kilometer-long city wall.

properties.name: Niphates (mountain)
properties.description: A mountain range in Armenia, belonging to the eastern Taurus massif.

properties.name: Nisibis/Antiochia
properties.description: Nisibis/Antiochia was an ancient city of Mesopotamia that began as part of an Aramaean kingdom that the Assyrian king Adad-Nirari II captured in 896 BC. Following its capture by Alexander the Great, the city became Antiochia Mygdonia under the Seleucids.

properties.name: Singaras
properties.description: A mountain range, now called Sinjar Mountain (Shengar/Shengal), located in northwestern Iraq.

properties.name: Fingrinhoe Roman Site
properties.description: A multi-acre site, now located within the bounds of the Fingringhoe Wick Nature Discovery Park in Colchester. The site may have been or included a Roman military supply base that was in use until ca. A.D. 120. The site included several structures, a ditched enclosure, and a possible villa.

properties.name: Tomb of Menidi
properties.description: A Mycenaean tholos tomb first discovered in 1872. It is one of four such tholoi known in Attica.

properties.name: Palace of Tupkish
properties.description: Palace at the Hurrian city Urkesh, constructed by Tupkish in the late third millennium BCE.

properties.name: A'ali Mound Cemetery
properties.description: A large complex of burial mounds located near the town of A'ali in central Bahrain. The burials date to the early Dilmun era, ca. 2050-1700 BCE.

properties.name: Anazarbos city wall
properties.description: The Anazarbos city wall visible today was built in the 10th century of the current era.

properties.name: Areopagus
properties.description: Named after a mythical trial of the god Ares, the Areopagus is a rocky outcropping in Athens located to the northwest of the acropolis. The hill was used as a meeting place for the Council of the Areopagus which functioned as a council of elders for the city of Athens. The Areopagus is also traditionally identified as the setting for Paul's sermon to Athens.

properties.name: Cathedral of St. James, Jerusalem
properties.description: A 12th-century Armenian church in Jerusalem, the principal church of the Armenian Patriarchate of Jerusalem.

properties.name: Dhu0101t Ku0101hl
properties.description: Large town in the Arabian Peninsula inhabited from the 4th century BCE-5th century CE. The town was the capital of the Kindah Kingdom.

properties.name: Santa Prisca
properties.description: A titular church on Rome's Aventine Hill dedicated to Saint Prisca. A Mithraeum dating to the late first century A.D. was discovered on the site in 1934.

properties.name: Via Ostiensis
properties.description: An ancient road running from Rome to Ostia, exiting the city walls of Rome at the Porta Trigemina.

properties.name: Via Nomentana
properties.description: The ancient road connecting Rome and Nomentum.

properties.name: Alepotrypa
properties.description: A cave in Diros Bay in Greece used as a settlement in the middle and late Neolithic Period. The site was sealed by an earthquake and abandoned around 3200 BCE.

properties.name: Polygonal wall of Roman castrum
properties.description: The polygonal masonry wall of the Roman castrum at Pyrgi encloses an area of ca. 5.7 ha.

properties.name: Armenia
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 90 B1 Armenia

properties.name: Tomb of Puimre at Thebes
properties.description: Tomb TT39 in the Theban Necropolis, the burial site of Puimre (or Puyemre), an Egyptian official of the 18th Dynasty.

properties.name: Puru1e6dir
properties.description: A fortress in the vicinity of Til-garimmu fortified by the Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721-705 BC) against Uraru1e6du.

properties.name: Temple of Olympian Zeus, Syracuse
properties.description: The Temple of Olympian Zeus is located approximately 3 km southwest of Syracuse on the Cyane river.

properties.name: Temple of Olympian Zeus, Athens
properties.description: The Temple of Olympian Zeus is also known as the Olympieion. A colossal temple dedicated to Zeus, it was built in three stages, beginning in 515 BCE and ending in 131 CE.

properties.name: Tall Mu016bzu0101n
properties.description: Urkesh or Urkish (the modern Tell Mozan) is a tell located in the foothills of the Taurus Mountains of northeastern Syria. Hurrians founded the site during the fourth millennium B.C.

properties.name: Gallo-Roman Theater of Lillebonne
properties.description: The Gallo-Roman Theater of Lillebonne was in use from the first to the third century.

properties.name: Via Valeria
properties.description: An ancient road from Rome to Corfinium.

properties.name: tribus Horatia
properties.description: The tribus Horatia was a rural tribe of ancient Rome.

properties.name: tribus Oufentina
properties.description: The tribus Oufentina was a later rural tribe of Rome, established in 318 B.C.

properties.name: Aurelian Walls
properties.description: The Aurelian Walls of Rome began as a fortification system built by Aurelian and Probus between 271 and 275. They enclose an area of approximately 1,400 hectares.

properties.name: Ezida (Kalhu)
properties.description: When Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud) became the principal administrative center of the Assyrian Empire in the ninth century BC, king Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883u2013859 BC) built (or rebuilt) numerous temples. One of those was dedicated to the god Nabu00fb. Unlike most of the religious buildings constructed at Kalhu, the Ezida (True House) was built in the southeast corner of the Citadel.

properties.name: Sebetti temple (Kalhu)
properties.description: When Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud) became the principal administrative center of the Assyrian Empire in the ninth century BC, king Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883u2013859 BC) built (or rebuilt) numerous temples. One of those was dedicated to the divine Sebetti. The location of this building is not known.

properties.name: Acropolis of Malthi
properties.description: The acropolis of ancient Dorion.

properties.name: Santa Costanza
properties.description: A fourth century AD structure along the Via Nomentana that was built by Constantine I as a mausoleum, originally housing the remains of his daughters Constantina and Helena. It was dedicated as a Christian church in the Middle Ages.

properties.name: Greek theater of Segesta
properties.description: Remains of a Greek theater at Segesta that was first built in the first half of the third century B.C.

properties.name: Ekiu0161ibgalekura
properties.description: The shrine/seat of the goddess Ninimma in the Egipar temple at Ur. The Sumerian ceremonial name Ekiu0161ibgalekura may mean House, Keeper of the Seal of the Ekur.

properties.name: Parthenon
properties.description: The poliadic temple of Athena located on the Athenian Acropolis and constructed at the height of Athenian power between 447 and 432 BCE. The Parthenon is the largest Doric temple in mainland Greece.

properties.name: Ay-ibu016br-u0161abu00fb
properties.description: The processional road of the god Marduk in Babylon, whose Akkadian ceremonial name means May the Arrogant Not Flourish. The street runs north-south through the city, from the Iu0161tar Gate to the Esagil temple. The northern stretch of Ay-ibu016br-u0161abu00fb is sometimes referred to as Iu0161tar-lamassi-ummu0101nu012bu0161u (The goddess Iu0161tar is the Guardian Angel of Her Troops).

properties.name: Larak
properties.description: A city located near the Tigris River, possibly east or northeast of Nippur.

properties.name: Baduldua
properties.description: The city wall of Sippar. Its Sumerian ceremonial name means Wall Built in Ancient Times. In the 7th century B.C., the wall was also called Badullisu00e2 (What Named in Ancient Times).

properties.name: Rocca San Silvestro, Campiglia Marittima
properties.description: The Rocca San Silvestro is a tenth century fortified village on Monte Rombolo near Campiglia Marittima in the Alta Maremma. The village was built in order to exploit rich mineral resources in the area.

properties.description: A rural tribe of ancient Rome.

properties.name: tribus Fabia
properties.description: The tribus Fabia was a rural tribe of Rome.
