properties.description: The oldest permanent settlement in the Troad.

properties.name: Rouweyha
properties.description: An ancient place, located in modern Syria, with remains of an ancient basilica, residential buildings, and several tombs. Inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2011 as part of the Ancient Villages of Northern Syria.

properties.name: Ajanta Caves
properties.description: The Ajanta Caves are among the earliest Buddhist cave monuments and date from the second and first centuries B.C. During the Gupta period (fifth and sixth centuries A.D.), additional decorated caves were added to the group.

properties.name: Roman theater of Suasa
properties.description: The Roman theater of Suasa was discovered in 2003 during excavations near the amphitheater. The semicircular structure measures ca. 55 meters in diameter and dates to the first century A.D.

properties.name: Theater
properties.description: The Theater of Aphrodisias dates to the second half of the first century B.C. and stands on the eastern slope of the acropolis.

properties.name: Tell Abu Salabikh
properties.description: Tell Abu Salabikh was the site of a small Sumerian city of the third millennium BC.

properties.name: Tigris/Diglitus (river)
properties.description: The Tigris river, one of the two great rivers that define Mesopotamia, flows 1,850 km from the Taurus Mountains to the Persian Gulf.

properties.name: Zoreh/Or(o)atis? (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 93 F3 Zoreh/Or(o)atis? fl.

properties.name: Antonine Wall
properties.description: A series of fortifications approximately 63 km in length, spanning the breadth of modern day Scotland between the Firth of Forth and the Firth of Clyde. The Antonine Wall was inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2008.

properties.name: Hadrian's Wall
properties.description: Hadrian's Wall or Vallum Aelium was the first of two Roman fortifications built across northern Britannia. The project was begun in A.D. 122 and the works eventually stretched from the River Tyne near the North Sea to the Solway Firth on the Irish Sea. The wall represented the northern limit of the Roman Empire.

properties.name: Graupius M.
properties.description: Site of Roman military victory over the native Caledonians in AD 83 or 84, chronicled in Tacitus' Agricola. Its location has never been conclusively identified, notwithstanding centuries of scholarly debate. Dozens of candidate sites have been proposed (and dismissed) over the years, however, the general consensus seems to agree upon a location somewhere in northeast Scotland extending north from Perthshire well into Aberdeenshire.

properties.name: Pinnata Castra
properties.description: The Roman legionary fortress at modern day Inchtuthil.

properties.name: Ardashir-Khurra/Gur/[Firuzabad]
properties.description: Ardashir-Khurra/Gur/[Firuzabad] was an ancient Persian city. Alexander of Macedonia destroyed the original settlement of Gu014dr, which was later revived by Ardashir I, founder of the Sassanid dynasty.

properties.name: Pasargadae/Batrakatash
properties.description: Pasargadae/Batrakatash was an ancient Persian city and the capital of Cyrus the Great (559u2013530 BC). It remained the capital until Cambyses II moved it to Susa. The site is listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

properties.name: Persepolis/Parsa/Persai/Sat Setun
properties.description: Persepolis/Parsa/Persai/Sat Setun was the ceremonial capital of the Achaemenid Empire. The origins of the settlement belong to the sixth century BC (ca. 515). The archaeological site was named as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1979.

properties.name: Qaleh Dukhtar
properties.description: The so-called Maiden Castle is a large fortification built by Ardashir I in the early third century A.D. It is located about 8 kilometers to the north of Firuzabad in modern Iran. Despite the distance involved, it is listed as part of the cultural landscape of Bam in the 2004 UNESCO World Heritage List.

properties.description: The temple of the goddess Anunnu012btu at Sippar-Anunnu012btu (=Sippar-Amnanum).

properties.name: Etemenanki
properties.description: The ziggurat of the god Marduk at Babylon. The Sumerian ceremonial name Etemenanki means House, Foundation Platform of Heaven and Underworld.

properties.name: Emeslam
properties.description: The temple of the god Nergal at Cutha. The Sumerian ceremonial name Emeslam means House, Warrior of the Netherworld.

properties.name: Emau0161dari
properties.description: The temple of the goddess Iu0161tar of Agade at Babylon. The Sumerian ceremonial name Emau0161dari means House of Animal Offerings. The Neo-Babylonian king Nabonidus rebuilt/renovated it.

properties.name: Ekunankuga
properties.description: The ziggurat of the god u0160amau0161 at Sippar. The Sumerian ceremonial name Ekunankuga means House, Pure Stairway of Heaven.

properties.name: Badnigerimhuluha
properties.description: Ninevehu2019s outer stone wall was called Badnigerimhuluha (Wall, Terrorizer of Enemies). It was constructed by the Neo-Assyrian king Sennacherib after he moved the Assyrian capital to Nineveh. The visible remains of the twelve-kilometer-long wall and some of its gates are still visible today.

properties.name: Guadalferza
properties.description: A Spanish castle and village located in the south of the province of Toledo, 18 km from Los Yu00e9benes, that belonged to the kingdom of Alfonso X. It is now known as Guadalerzas.

properties.name: Regio II, Pompeii
properties.description: The so-called Regio II, an archaeological subdivision located in the eastern section of Pompeii, includes the Amphitheater and the Large Palaestra, as well as a number of residences and commercial structures.

properties.name: Great Wall of Gorgan
properties.description: A linear fortification system, probably built in the Parthian period and used during the Sasanian period, the so-called Great Wall of Gorgan stretches almost 200 km from the east coast of the Caspian Sea to near the town of Pishkamar in modern Iran. If the fortification system had a name in antiquity, it has not survived.

properties.name: Parthyene/Parthia

properties.name: Bactra/Zariaspa

properties.name: Dilbarjin
properties.description: Dilbarjin is an ancient city of northern Afghanistan. The site may have been founded under the Achaemenid Empire. Under the Kushan Empire, the site was a fortified local center of some importance.

properties.name: Emshi tepe
properties.description: Emshi tepe is located in Jauzjan Province to the northeast of Shibarghan. Material on the site dates to the Hellenistic, Kushan, and Sassanian/Kushano-Sassanian periods.

properties.name: Ancient Egypt (region)
properties.description: The ancient kingdom(s) and region of Egypt as understood by the Egyptians themselves, their neighbors, and their successors. Individual administrative districts, provinces, nomes, and the like have separate place resources in Pleiades.

properties.name: Africa Proconsularis (Roman province)
properties.description: The late Republican and early Roman imperial province, initially subdivided into two provinces known as Africa vetus and Africa nova, but merged into one province ca. 35 B.C.

properties.name: Aquitania (Roman province)
properties.description: A Roman province formed in 27 B.C. by Augustus. According to Strabo, it incorporated the territories of the Aquitani and 14 other peoples whose territories were located between the Garumna and Liger rivers.

properties.name: Arabia (province)
properties.description: A Roman province founded under Trajan shortly after 22 March 106 CE. It included the territory to the east of the Jordan river and the Sinai peninsula to the Red Sea.

properties.name: Armenia Minor (Roman eparcheia)
properties.description: Territory west of the Euphrates and Armenia (Roman province) included in the province of Cappadocia by Vespasian.

properties.name: Britannia (province)
properties.description: A province of the Roman Empire at the Death of Trajan (117 CE).

properties.name: Dacia Porolissensis (province)
properties.description: Sometime after AD 124, Dacia Superior was sub-divided into two provinces: Dacia Apulensis and Dacia Porolissensis.

properties.name: Iudaea (province)
properties.description: The Roman province of Iudaea, incorporating the historical regions of Judea, Samaria, and Idumaea, was established in 6 CE, when the former tetrarchy of Herod Archelaus came under direct Roman administration. Following the Bar Kokhba War (132-135), Hadrian changed the province's name to Palaestina, and in the mid- to late 4th century CE the area was divided into three provinces (Palaestina Prima, Secunda, and Tertia or Salutaris).

properties.name: Roman theater at Spoletium
properties.description: The Roman theater at Spoletium dates to the first century B.C.

properties.name: Marsicovetere Roman villa
properties.description: A Roman villa rustica belonging to the senatorial family of the Bruttii Praesentes that has been connected with Bruttia Crispina, the wife of Commodus. The villa was inhabited from the second century B.C. to the seventh century A.D. The villa's archaeological remains are found in the locality of Barricelle in the territory of the community of Marsicovetere in the province of Potenza.

properties.name: Bougon
properties.description: Bougon is the site of five Neolithic barrows located in Poitou-Charentes, France. The earliest dates ca. 4800 BC.

properties.name: Haghartsin
properties.description: Armenian monastery complex constructed between the 9th-13th centuries CE.

properties.name: Leuctra tropaion
properties.description: A trophy monument erected by the Thebans following their defeat of the Spartans in 371 BC.

properties.name: Roman theater of Scythopolis
properties.description: The Roman theater of Scythopolis.

properties.name: Elginhaugh Roman fort
properties.description: Site of the most completely excavated timber-built auxiliary fort (with annexe) in the Roman Empire, situated in present-day Midlothian, Scotland. Roman occupation was short-lived, having been established in the early 70s CE and abandoned in or shortly after 86. Now completely built over by the Royal Bank of Scotland Data Centre.

properties.name: Mura Serviane, Anagni
properties.description: An ancient opus quadratum wall at Anagni referred to as Mura Serviane based on its construction technique.

properties.name: Nemyriv Hillfort
properties.description: Scythian hillfort site located on the Southern Bug River near the modern town of Nemyriv. The site was primarily inhabited in the early Iron Age (8th-6th centuries BCE), with additional deposits from the Chalcolithic Age, the Bronze Age, the La Tene period, the Chernyakov Culture, and the Middle Ages.

properties.name: Santuario di Pyrgi
properties.description: A sanctuary with twin temples located at the Etruscan port. The Pyrgi sanctuary was initially excavated by Massimo Pallottino in 1957. The so-called Pyrgi Plaques were discovered here in 1964.

properties.description: The shrine in the Egipar temple at Ur. The Sumerian ceremonial name Eanu0161ar means House of All Heaven.

properties.name: Eadgigi
properties.description: The shrine/seat of the god Nusku in the Egipar temple at Ur. The Sumerian ceremonial name Eadgigi means House of the Counsellor.

properties.name: Suteans
properties.description: A West Semitic semi-nomadic group attested principally in Babylonia during the first millennium B. C. The Sutu00fb are also attested in cuneiform sources of the second millennium B.C., including several of the Amarna Letters, and these earlier texts provide evidence for the Suteans living in the Levant and Syria, west of the Euphrates River.

properties.name: Nu0113med-Enlil
properties.description: The outer wall of Babylon was called by the ceremonial Akkadian name Nu0113med-Enlil/ Nu0113metti-Enlil, which means Bulwark of the God Enlil. According to the text Tintir = Babylon, Nu0113med-Enlil (and the inner wall Imgur-Enlil) had eight city gates, four on the eastern side of the Euphrates and four on the western side of the river. The Assyrian kings Esarhaddon and Ashurbanipal and the Babylonian kings Nabopolassar, Nebuchadnezzar II, and Nebonidus all undertook construction on Babylonu2019s outer wall.

properties.name: Tell Wilaya
properties.description: Tell Wilaya is a small site that was occupied from the Jemdet Nasr Period to the Old Babylonian Period. Its ancient name is not known, but it may have been Keu0161.

properties.name: Ugal-amaru
properties.description: According to an inscription of the Neo-Babylonian king Nabonidus, the name of the wall of Cutha was Ugal-amaru, whose ceremonial name means Great Storm, (which is) a Deluge.

properties.name: Imgur-Enlil
properties.description: The great, inner wall of Babylon was called by the ceremonial Akkadian name Imgur-Enlil, which means The God Enlil Showed Favor. According to the text Tintir = Babylon, Imgur-Enlil had eight city gates, four on the eastern side of the Euphrates and four on the western side of the river. The Assyrian kings Esarhaddon and Ashurbanipal and the Babylonian kings Nabopolassar, Nebuchadnezzar II, and Nebonidus all undertook construction on Babylonu2019s great wall. Imgur-Enlil is one of the seven wonders of the ancient according to some classical sources.

properties.name: Caepionis Monu.
properties.description: Caepionis Monumentum (Tower of Caepio) was a tower-cum-lighthouse built by the Roman proconsul Quintus Servilius Caepio in 140 BC. The aim was to make the Salmedina reef at the mouth of the river Baitis (Guadalquivir) navigable. The modern toponym is Chipiona.

properties.name: Via Cassia
properties.description: An ancient Roman road branching off from the Via Flaminia and continuing to Luna where it joined the Via Aurelia. The Via Cassia post-dates the Via Amerina and was built after 240 B.C. It combined new construction with re-use of pre-existing roads and tracks.

properties.name: Via Clodia
properties.description: An ancient Roman road.

properties.name: Klin-Yar
properties.description: A burial ground near the modern town of Kislovodsk in the North Caucasus. The site contains 270 burials associated with the Iron Age Koban culture and the early medieval Sarmatians and Alans.

properties.name: Torre Romana, Novaria
properties.description: A surviving Roman defensive tower.

properties.name: Kastri
properties.description: The fortified settlement of Kastri near Chalandriani on the Cycladic island of Syros is an important Early Cycladic II site. This fortified hill-top settlement is a very early example of a site in the Aegean with a fortification wall reinforced by means of stone bastions.

properties.name: Roman cistern
properties.description: A Roman cistern of the early second century A.D.

properties.name: Roman amphitheater at Lucus Feroniae
properties.description: The Roman amphitheater at Lucus Feroniae was financed by one M. Silius Epaphroditus, who in turn received the title patronus. The structure dates to the reign of Tiberius.

properties.name: Roman amphitheater at Lucera
properties.description: An amphitheater dating to the time of Augustus.

properties.name: Pyramid of Unas
properties.description: A pyramid at Saqqara built for Unas, the final ruler of Egypt's Fifth Dynasty.

properties.name: Tigurini
properties.description: A sub-tribe of the Helvetii.

properties.name: Myrtonion
properties.description: A fortress in Thrace, whose precise location is now unknown.

properties.name: Arch of Galerius
properties.description: The extant remains of a triumphal arch, constructed from 298 to 299 CE and dedicated in 303 CE under the tetrarch Galerius. It commemorates the capture of Ctesiphon from the Sassanids and forms part of a monumental entrance to the palace of Galerius.

properties.name: Oluz Hu00f6yu00fck
properties.description: Mound site in Amasya province, Turkey. First inhabited in the Early Bronze Age (ca. 4500 BCE), the site was abandoned sometime during the Hittite Period (15th-13th centuries BCE). It was briefly resettled during the Iron Age-Hellenistic period (8th-1st centuries BCE).

properties.name: El-Qitar
properties.description: Bronze Age fortified site located on the Euphrates in Syria.

properties.name: Ku0227bul
properties.description: A place from the TAVO Index

properties.name: Damietta Branch
properties.description: The Damietta branch is an eastern distributary of the Nile Delta and gives its name to an associated settlement.

properties.name: Tel Erani
properties.description: One of the largest Early Bronze Age mounds in the southern Levant, located approximately 20 km east of Ashkelon. The site shows signs of habitation as early as the Chalcolithic Era, with a significant remains from the Bronze Age and additional remains from the Iron Age, Persian, Hellenistic, and Islamic periods.

properties.name: Via Augusta
properties.description: A Roman road stretching some 1,500 km from Cu00e1diz to the Coll de Panissars.

properties.name: Via Appia
properties.description: An early Roman road (via publica) originating at Rome and terminating at Brundisium, the Via Appia was begun in the fourth century B.C. by the censor Appius Claudius Caecus. The Latin author Statius described the Via Appia as queen of the long roads.

properties.name: Ehilikalamma
properties.description: The temple of the goddess Au0161ratu, Ehilikalamma (u201cHouse of the Luxuriance of the Landu201d), was located in the Ka-dingirra district (modern Sahn) of Babylon. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, this was one of four temples in that part of the city, which was located in the northern part of the eastern half of Babylon.

properties.name: Via Labicana
properties.description: An ancient Roman road connecting Rome and Labicum.

properties.name: Tell Qasile
properties.description: Archaeological site on the Yarkon River in modern Tel Aviv, identified as a Philistine city inhabited during the 12th and 11th centuries BCE.

properties.name: St Peters Church, Flawford
properties.description: A ruined Medieval church located on the site of a Roman villa.

properties.name: House of the Centenary
properties.description: A Pompeian domus re-discovered in 1879, the so-called House of the Centenary is among the largest domus in Pompeii.

properties.name: Pani Loriga
properties.description: A fortified Phoenico-Punic settlement on Sardinia with two necropoleis.

properties.name: Ruinas de Tru00f3ia
properties.description: The Tru00f3ia peninsula in Portugal is the site of a large facility for the production of Roman fish sauce (garum) and ruins of a large industrial area for the processing has been excacated there.

properties.name: Sanctuary at Agios Konstantinos (Methana)
properties.description: A Late Helladic sanctuary was excavated by Helene Konstolakis-Jiannopoulou in 1990 near the chapel of Agios Konstantinos and Elenis. Activity at this site dates between 1500 and 1300 B.C.

properties.name: Iuktas
properties.description: A Minoan peak sanctuary on Juktas that served the Minoan palace of Knossos. The site was first excavated in 1909 by Sir Arthur Evans. The site was in use from Early to Late Bronze Age.

properties.name: Tall-e Bakun B
properties.description: The second of the two mounds comprising the Tall-e Bakun site.

properties.name: Tall-e Bakun A
properties.description: The larger of the two mounds that make up the Tall-e Bakun site.

properties.name: Sanctuary of Apollo
properties.description: The Sanctuary of Apollo near Amyklai is a stoa-like building that enclosed a colossal statue of Apollo on three sides and was decorated with reliefs. The tomb of Hyacinthus is used as a statue base, combining the two local deities together.

properties.name: Iu0161tar Gate
properties.description: The Iu0161tar Gate is the most famous of Babylon's eight city gates and is situated on the northeastern side of the inner city, directly north of the Kadingirra quarter. King Nebuchadnezzar II built the gate ca. 575 B.C.

properties.name: Sphinx Temple
properties.description: The Old Kingdom temple associated with the Great Sphinx of Giza and assigned to the reign of Khafre.

properties.name: E(...)gakuga
properties.description: The shrine/seat of the god Ennugi in the Egipar temple at Ur. The name is damaged and the complete Sumerian ceremonial name of the structure is not known.

properties.name: Hiera Oikia at Eleusis
properties.description: The so-called Hiera Oikia is a multi-room structure dating to the 7th century BC in the sanctuary of Demeter of Kore at Eleusis.

properties.name: Temple of Athena Pronaia
properties.description: The Temple of Athena Pronaia, located at Delphi, is a peripteral Doric building (6 x 12 columns). It was built ca. 500 BC and is the largest building in the sanctuary of Athena Pronaia.

properties.name: Enlil temple (Kalhu)
properties.description: When Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud) became the principal administrative center of the Assyrian Empire in the ninth century BC, king Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883u2013859 BC) built (or rebuilt) numerous temples. One of those was dedicated to the god Enlil. Although its location is not known, the Enlil temple at Kalhu is thought to have been situated within the Ninurta temple complex, in the northwest corner of the citadel.

properties.name: Adad-u0160ala temple (Kalhu)
properties.description: When Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud) became the principal administrative center of the Assyrian Empire in the ninth century BC, king Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883u2013859 BC) built (or rebuilt) numerous temples. One of those was dedicated to the god Adad and the goddess u0160ala. Although its location is not known, the Adad-u0160ala temple at Kalhu is thought to have been situated within the Ninurta temple complex, in the northwest corner of the citadel.

properties.name: Su00een temple (Kalhu)
properties.description: When Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud) became the principal administrative center of the Assyrian Empire in the ninth century BC, king Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883u2013859 BC) built (or rebuilt) numerous temples. One of those was dedicated to the moon-god Su00een. Although its location is not known, the Su00een temple at Kalhu is thought to have been situated within the Ninurta temple complex, in the northwest corner of the citadel.

properties.name: Guadau00edra (river)
properties.description: A tributary of the Guadalquivir river that rises in Pozo Amargo in the province of Cadiz.

properties.name: Bouqras
properties.description: A Neolithic tell site in eastern Syria, inhabited from ca. 7400-6200 BCE.

properties.name: Sanctuaries of Apollo Deiradiotes and Athena Oxyderkes
properties.description: At Argos, Pausanias mentions both the sanctuary of Apollo Deiradiotes (Apollo of the ridge) and the sanctuary of Athena Oxyderkes (Athena the clear-sighted).

properties.name: Celegeri
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 21 C6 Celegeri

properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 21 A2 Cusus fl.

properties.name: Dacia
properties.description: Dacia was a region inhabited by the Dacians or Getae. A Dacian kingdom existed from ca. the early first century BC until the Roman conquest under Trajan in AD 106.

properties.name: Savus (river)
properties.description: A river of Central Europe and a right tributary of the Danube.

properties.name: Scordisci
properties.description: The Scordisci were a Gallic people of the Iron Age inhabiting what is now Serbia. Their territory centered on the confluence of the Savus (Sava), Dravus (Drava), and Danube rivers.

properties.name: u00c7obantepe
properties.description: An Early to Middle Bronze Age site located on the southern shore of the Dardanelles.

properties.name: Ajina Tepe
properties.description: Buddhist monastery in southern Tajikistan dated the the 7th-8th centuries CE.

properties.name: Rahi-ilu
properties.description: An unlocated city/town in the kingdom of Suhu that was situated on an island in the Euphrates River.

properties.name: Bir Massouda
properties.description: An archaeological site in Carthage showing signs of continuous habitation from ca. 760 BCE-700 CE.

properties.name: Ipatovo-3 Kurgan
properties.description: A Bronze Age kurgan site in the Stavropol region.

properties.name: Kunulua/Tell Tayinat
properties.description: Tell Tayinat (ancient Kunulua) is a large site (comprising both a sizeable citadel and a sprawling lower town) located at the northern bend of the Orontes River, ca. 30 km southeast of Antakya (ancient Antioch). Strategically located, this fortified city served as a royal capital for various historically-attested Bronze and Iron Age kingdoms (ca. 3200-600 B.C.). In 738 B.C., the Assyrian king Tiglath-pileser III conquered Kunulua (alternately called Kinalua), then the royal city of Syro-Hittite kingdom of Patina, annexed it, and transformed it into an important provincial administrative center. Textual evidence found at the site (e.g., a large tablet inscribed with a copy of Esarhaddonu2019s Succession Treaty) leaves little doubt that Kunulua should be identified as Tell Tayinat.

properties.name: Manoppello Roman Villa
properties.description: A Late Republican villa in Abruzzo that later became a productive estate. The archaeological remains of the villa are located in the locality of Piano S. Maria Arabona in Manoppello, Italy.

properties.name: Harappa
properties.description: A Bronze Age fortified city located on the Ravi River, inhabited from the fourth through the second millennia BCE, Harappa was one of the most important settlements of the Indus Valley Civilization.

properties.name: Tower 1 (Dura-Europos)
properties.description: A rectangular defensive tower located on the northern end of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. The fortifications were built ca. 150 BCE. They were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.

properties.name: Yesemek
properties.description: Quarry and sculpture workshop founded under the Hittite king Suppiluliuma in the 14th century BCE.

properties.name: El Algarve
properties.description: El Algarve is a region that is today located in the south of Portugal. Historically, it once belonged to the kingdom of Alfonso X.

properties.name: Tel Hazor
properties.description: Tel Hazor (Hebrew: u05eau05dc u05d7u05e6u05d5u05e8u200eu200e) is an archaeological site located in the southern Hula Valley overlooking Lake Merom. From the Middle Bronze Age to the Israelite period in the ninth century B.C., Hazor was the largest fortified city in the region. It served as a commercial center with links to Babylon and Syria. In the Book of Joshua, Hazor is described as u201cthe head of all those kingdomsu201d (Josh. 11:10).

properties.name: Panaztepe
properties.description: A mound site located approximately 35 km northwest of modern Izmir, Turkey, with signs of habitation from the 3rd millennium BCE through the early Iron Age.

properties.name: Tepe Gawra
properties.description: An ancient Mesopotamian settlement located in the Mosul region of northwest Iraq.

properties.name: Til-Bau0161eru00ea
properties.description: An unwalled town mentioned in Neo-Assyrian sources that is identified with Tell Bau0161ir.

properties.name: Stanegate
properties.description: An important Roman military road built in what is now northern England, linking Corbridge in the east and Carlisle in the west. A later western addition may have linked the fort at Kirkbride.

properties.description: The Tarn river.

An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 14 D1 no. 6 (Langon)

properties.name: Ermine Street
properties.description: The Ermine Street was a major Roman road of Britain, running from Londinium to Colonia Lindum and Eburacum.

properties.name: Temple of Khnum at Esna
properties.description: A temple dedicated to the god Khnum constructed during the Ptolemaic and Roman period in the city of Esna (Latopolis).

properties.name: Temple of Artemis Agrotera
properties.description: A temple of Artemis on the Ilissos that marks the spot where the goddess first hunted after arriving from Delos. The archaeological remains of the site are found on the modern Ardettou Street in Athens.

properties.name: Balochistan (region)
properties.description: A desert and mountainous region located between the Plateau of Iran and the Indian subcontinent, comprising the modern regions of southeastern Iran (Sistan and Baluchestan province), western Pakistan (Balochistan province), and southern Afghanistan (Nimruz, Helmand and Kandahar provinces). The region's name is derived from the Baloch people, who have inhabited the region since at least the ninth century CE. In antiquity, the southern part of the region, along the coast of the Arabian Sea, was known as Maka in the Achaemenid period and Gedrosia in the Hellenistic period.

properties.name: 'Ir David/Wadi Hilweh
properties.description: The City of David is the name given in the 20th century to an archaeological site located in the Arab neighborhood of Wadi Hilweh, located south of the Temple Mount and the Ophel in East Jerusalem. The site contains pottery from as early as the Chalcolithic Age, and has been proposed as a possible original core of the city of Jerusalem. The Silwa necropolis, a burial site dated to the 9th-7th centuries BCE, is located within this area.

properties.name: Passo Lombardo
properties.description: A villa rustica in Rome's suburbium with evidence for domestic production in the form of vats made from peperino tuff.

properties.name: Villa romana delle Grotte
properties.description: A villa dating to the final quarter of the first century BC located on a headland overlooking Portoferraio on the island of Elba.

properties.name: Tenginskaya II
properties.description: A Meotian settlement and necropolis near the village of Tenginskaya, inhabited from the sixth to fourth centuries BCE.

properties.name: Kurhan Perep'yatykha
properties.description: A large Scythian burial mound that dates to the seventh and sixth centuries B.C.

properties.name: Limen to Kaisareiou
properties.description: A harbor constructed in Constantinople during the reign of Theodosius I; 37 Byzantine-era shipwrecks have been excavated from the harbor site.

properties.name: Roman Baths (Bath)
properties.description: Bathhouse complex in Aquae Sulis, modern-day Bath. This well-preserved site is now a museum and the bathing complex itself is below modern street-level.

properties.name: Crystal Palace Pub, Bath
properties.description: Remains of sequence of Romano-British deposits found in the cellar of a pub in modern-day Bath.

properties.name: Smyrnophoros Chora
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 4 B3 Smyrnophoros Chora

properties.name: Syagros? Pr.
properties.description: A promontory of the southern coast of Arabia.

properties.name: T(h)onabaei
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 4 C2 T(h)onabaei

properties.name: Trogodytice
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 4 A2 Trogodytice

properties.name: Zamareni?
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 4 B2 Zamareni?

properties.name: Zenobiou (islands)
properties.description: The Khuriya Muriya Islands are a group of five islands in the Arabian Sea.

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 40 C4 unnamed bridge (near Compitum ad Confluentes)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 40 C4 unnamed bridge (over Utens? fl., near S. Vito di Rimini)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 40 D1 unnamed bridge (at Ad Sanos (near S. Anastasio))

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 40 D1 unnamed bridge (at Fiumicino, nearer to (H)Eraclia)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 40 D1 unnamed bridge (at Ceggia, Fondo Loro, further from (H)Eraclia)

properties.name: Fossa Augusta
properties.description: A canal connecting the Po river to the harbor of Ravenna.

properties.name: Fossa Flavia
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 40 C3 Fossa Flavia

properties.name: Centuriation near Vicetia
properties.description: Roman centuriation to the northwest of Vicetia (modern Vicenza in Italy)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 40 A2 unnamed centuriation (near Cadianum (Verona))

properties.name: Untitled

properties.name: Untitled

properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 40 C1 unnamed centuriation (N Altinum)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 40 C2 unnamed centuriation (NE Patavium)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 40 C4 unnamed centuriation (Ariminum, near Compitum ad Confluentes)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 40 C4 unnamed centuriation (Caesena)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 40 C4 unnamed centuriation (Forum Popilii)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 40 D1 unnamed centuriation (Iulia Concordia)

properties.name: Ad Fines
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 41 C3 Ad Fines

properties.name: Alma (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 41 D4 Alma fl.

properties.name: Apuani
properties.description: The Apuani were a Ligurian tribe of northwest Italy.

properties.name: Arnus (river)
properties.description: The Arno river flows from its origin at Mount Falterona to the Marina di Pisa where it empties into the Tyrrhenian Sea.

properties.name: Caecina (river)
properties.description: The Cecina river flows through Etruria and empties into the Tyrrhenian Sea near Vada Volaterrana. The river course passed through the ancient territory of the Etruscan city of Volterra.

properties.name: Frigidus (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 41 C1 Frigidus fl.

properties.name: Friniates
properties.description: The Friniates were an ancient tribe of Liguria.

properties.name: Fufluna/Populonium
properties.description: Populonia likely derives its name from the Etruscan god 'Fufluns' and was an important maritime and commercial center of Etruria located in the Colline Metallifere.

properties.name: Planasia (island)
properties.description: Planasia (modern Pianosa) is an island of the Tuscan archipelago to which Agrippa Postumus was exiled by Augustus in A.D. 6 or 7.

properties.name: Umbro (river)
properties.description: A river of Etruria that flows from Castelnuovo Berardenga to the Tyrrhenian Sea.

properties.name: Vatl/Vetulonia
properties.description: The Etruscan Vatluna resisted Rome's influence in the seventh century, although the city may have been the source of Rome's adoption of the curule chair and the fasces.

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 41 C3 unnamed bridge (at Calignaia, NW Vada Volaterrana)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 41 C3 unnamed bridge (near Antignano)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 41 E4 unnamed bridge (Telamon)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 41 C2 unnamed centuriation (SE Taberna Frigida)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 41 C2 unnamed centuriation (Pisae)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 41 D2 unnamed centuriation (Luca)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 41 E2 unnamed centuriation (Ad Solaria)

properties.name: Acquarossa
properties.description: Acquarossa was an Etruscan settlement that was abandoned in the sixth century BC. The settlement occupied a steep-sided plateau and had an area of approximately 32 ha. Its ancient name is unknown.

properties.name: Ad Aesim
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 D2 Ad Aesim

properties.name: Ad Fines/Ad Casas Caesarianas
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 B1 Ad Fines/Ad Casas Caesarianas

properties.name: Ad Statuas
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 B2 Ad Statuas

properties.name: Ager Gallicus (region)
properties.description: A region of Italy in which Gallic settlement had taken place after 400 BC. This territory was captured by Rome following the battle of Sentinum in 295 BC.

properties.name: Albinia (river)
properties.description: The Albegna is a river of southern Tuscany and flows from Monte Amiata to the Tyrrhenian Sea.

properties.name: Amiternum
properties.description: Amiternum was an ancient settlement of the Sabines that Rome captured in 293 BC. The settlement was situated at the intersection of four Roman roads: the Via Caecilia, the Via Claudia Nova, and the two branches of the Via Salaria. The historian Sallust was born at Amiternum in 86 B.C.

properties.name: Ancon(a)
properties.description: A port city founded by colonists from Syracuse in 387 BC.

properties.name: Aquae Apollinares
properties.description: The Aquae Apollinares were thermal springs located between Careiae and Tarquinii, perhaps to be associated with the Bagni di Stigliano or Bagni di Vicarello.

properties.name: Aquae Apollinares Novae
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 C4 Aquae Apollinares Novae

properties.name: Armenta (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 B4 Armenta fl.

properties.name: Avens (river)
properties.description: A river of the Sabine territory.

properties.name: Caletranus Ager
properties.description: The Caletranus Ager was the territory surrounding the Etruscan city of Caletra.

properties.name: Casuentillani
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 B1 Casuentillani

properties.name: *Cingulus M.
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 E2 *Cingulus M.

properties.name: Clitumnus (river)
properties.description: A small river of Umbria.

properties.name: *Cluentus (river)
properties.description: The Chienti river is found in Italy's Marche region. It flows from near Serravalle di Chienti to the Lago di Pievefavera and from there it joins the Fiastra river and eventually flows into the Adriatic Sea.

properties.name: Cunerum Pr.
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 F1 Cunerum Pr.

properties.name: Etruria/Tuscia (region)
properties.description: Etruria/Tuscia was an ancient region of Central Italy inhabited by the Etruscans.

properties.name: Falerii
properties.description: A fortified town located some 6 km from Falerii Veteres and established by the ancient Romans ca. 241 B.C.

properties.name: Falisci
properties.description: The name for a group of Italic people who occupied the Ager Faliscus within Etruria.

properties.name: Farfarus (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 D4 Farfarus fl.

properties.name: Flaminia
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 D1 Flaminia

properties.name: Flusor (river)
properties.description: The Potenza river.

properties.name: Grotte di Torri
properties.description: Grotte di Torri is located on the left bank of the Tiber river in the modern comune of Montopoli di Sabina. It has been inhabited since pre-Roman times.

properties.name: Lucus Feroniae
properties.description: A sanctuary and grove of Feronia and an associated settlement located along the Via Tiberina in the territory of Capena.

properties.name: Marsi
properties.description: The Marsi were an ancient Italic tribe. Their chief center was located at Marruvium.

properties.name: Marta (river)
properties.description: The Marta river flows from Lake Bolsena to the Tyrrhenian Sea. Its course flows past both Tuscania and Tarquinia and enters the Tyrrhenian Sea near Lido di Tarquinia.

properties.name: Matrinus? (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 F3 Matrinus? fl.

properties.name: Montefortino
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 D2 Montefortino

properties.name: Naharcer
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 D3 Naharcer

properties.name: Nar (river)
properties.description: The Nera river, a tributary of the Tiber.

properties.name: Nelurus (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 D1 Nelurus fl.

properties.name: [Orcla]
properties.description: [Orcla] or Norchia is an ancient Etruscan settlement located near Tarquinia and along the line of the Roman Via Clodia.

properties.name: Osa (river)
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 A3 Osa fl.

properties.name: Paeligni
properties.description: An ancient Oscan tribe of eastern Italy, the Paeligni are mentioned in the historical sources first in the fourth century BC when they oppose Rome during the Second Samnite War. The Paeligni came into alliance with Rome at the end of the fourth century BC but again took sides against Rome in the Social War.

properties.name: Picenum (region)
properties.description: Picenum was a region of Central Italy, extending along the coast of the Adriatic Sea from the mouth of the Aesis to that of the Matrinus, and inland as far as the central Apennines.

properties.name: Praetuttii
properties.description: The Praetuttii were an ancient tribe of central Italy.

properties.name: Rosia Campus
properties.description: A plain in the territory of the Sabines near Reate, reputed to have the most fertile soils in Italy.

properties.name: Sabini
properties.description: The Sabini (Sabines) were an Italic tribe of central Italy and belonged to the Osco-Umbrian language group. Their territory straddled parts of the modern regions of Lazio, Umbria, and the Abruzzo. Ancient writers connect them with Rome at the time of its foundation, as represented by the episode of the 'rape of the Sabine women' reported by various ancient authors.

properties.name: San Giuliano
properties.description: An Etruscan settlement evidenced by its extensive, surviving necropolis, which now lies within the Parco Naturale Regionale Marturanum in the administrative territory of Barbarano Romano, Italy. Its modern name is transferred from a nearby medieval church.

properties.name: Sappinates?
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 B1 Sappinates?

properties.name: Sepernates?
properties.description: An ancient people of Etruria inhabiting the area around Nazzano Romano.

properties.name: Settefinestre
properties.description: A Late Republican Roman slave-run villa owned by the senatorial family of the Volusii.

properties.name: Soracte M.
properties.description: Soracte M. (Monte Soratte) is a mountain near Rome, Italy, the highest peak of which rises to 691 masl (2,267 ft). A site of ritual activity in antiquity, the mountain was sacred to Dis Pater.

properties.name: Tarchna/Tarquinii
properties.description: An ancient city of Etruria and the leading city of the doudecim populi Etruriae, Tarquinia (called Tarch(u)na or Tarchna in Etruscan) was a major urban center of ancient Italy.

properties.name: Tetricus M.
properties.description: Tetricus M., a mountain group in Italy, part of the central Apennines.

properties.name: Tinea (river)
properties.description: The Topino river in Umbria.

properties.name: Tres Tabernae
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 D3 Tres Tabernae

properties.name: Truentus (river)
properties.description: A river of Picenum that flows from its source on the Gran Sasso d'Italia to the Adriatic Sea at Porto d'Ascoli.

properties.name: Umbria (region)
properties.description: The eponymous region of the Umbri, an ancient Italic people who spoke the Umbrian language. The physical geography of the landlocked region is hilly and dominated by the Appennine Mountains.

properties.name: *Umbro (river)
properties.description: The Ambra flows from the foot of Monte Luco to the Arno river.

properties.name: Urvinum Hortense
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 D3 Urvinum Hortense

properties.name: Vadimonis (lake)
properties.description: A partially dry lake of ancient Etruria near Orte. The Romans were victorious in two battles fought against the Etruscans there (310 and 283 BC).

properties.name: Velini L.
properties.description: A lake formed by three rivers (Avens, Himella and Tolenus) in the territory of the Sabines.

properties.name: Vestini
properties.description: The Vestini were an ancient tribe of Italy and lived in the southern part of the modern Abruzzo, between the Gran Sasso and the northern bank of the Aterno river. A major center was located at Pitinum.

properties.name: Volusii
properties.description: A villa associated with the Volusii Saturnini built ca. 50 B.C.

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 A1 unnamed aqueduct (Florentia)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An aqueduct located near the sulphurous springs at Aquae Tauri, northeast of Centumcellae.

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 D3 unnamed aqueduct (Spoletium)

properties.name: Unnamed aqueduct near Amiternum
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 E4 unnamed aqueduct (near Amiternum)

properties.name: Unnamed bridge
properties.description: An unnamed ancient bridge located on the Via Aurelia over the Osa river at Telamon.

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 B4 unnamed bridge (near Aquae Apollinares? on road to Tarquinii at La Mola)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 C4 unnamed bridge group (on Via Cassia, near Sorrina)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 C4 unnamed bridge group (on Via Amerina, near Nepet)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 A1 unnamed centuriation (Florentia)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 A3 unnamed centuriation (Heba)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 A4 unnamed centuriation (Cosa)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 D3 unnamed centuriation (Hispellum)

properties.name: Untitled
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 E1 unnamed centuriation (Fanum Fortunae)

properties.name: Cingilia
properties.description: A settlement of the Vestini, now unlocated, that, according to Livy, Iunius Brutus captured in 325 B.C.

properties.name: Cutina
properties.description: An ancient settlement, attested by literary or documentary sources, whose precise location cannot be determined today

properties.name: Forum Brentani/Brentanorum
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 unlocated Forum Brentani/Brentanorum

properties.name: Novana
properties.description: Novana, now unlocated, was a town of Picenum that is only known via Pliny's Natural History. The textual description places the site near Asculum and Cupra.

properties.name: Novem Pagi
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 unlocated Novem Pagi

properties.name: Sacrata
properties.description: Attested on the Peutinger Map, this road station near the Adriatic coast in Italy cannot be located with certainty today.

properties.name: Solinates
properties.description: An ancient Umbrian people whose territory is now unlocated.

properties.name: Traiana
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 42 unlocated Traiana

properties.name: Usidicani
properties.description: An ancient people whose territory is unlocated

properties.name: Ad Aquas Salvias
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 43 B2 Ad Aquas Salvias

properties.name: Aeflanus M.
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 43 D2 Aeflanus M.

properties.name: Villa degli Antonini
properties.description: The so-called 'Villa of the Antonines', located near Genzano di Roma in the Alban Hills, lies just south of the Via Appia between the road's 18th and 19th milestones.

properties.name: Campoverde
properties.description: Campoverde (Lazio) lies some 60 km south of Rome. In 1977-1978 a quantity of votive material was recovered from a body of water known as the Laghetto del Monsignore. This spring-fed body of water was interpreted as an open-air votive depository.

properties.name: Capitolium
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 43 B2 Capitolium

properties.name: Castra Albana
properties.description: Castra Albana was a permanent, fortified camp of the Legio II Parthica constructed during the Severan period.

properties.name: La Cecchina
properties.description: The so-called Torraccio della Cecchina is a Roman funereal monument dating to the second century A.D. It is located at the ninth kilometer of the modern Via Nomentana.

properties.name: Crepaddosso
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 43 D3 Crepaddosso

properties.name: Diana, T.
properties.description: A site sacred to Diana near Lake Nemi, comprised of a Tuscan-style sanctuary and a sacred grove.

properties.name: Villa Gordiani
properties.description: A third century A.D. villa complex along the Via Praenestina connected with Gordian I, Gordian II, and Gordian III.

properties.name: Hernici
properties.description: The Hernici (Hernicans) were an Italic tribe of first millennium B.C. Latium. Their territory was bounded by the Trerus fl. (Sacco) and the Lacus Fucinus (Fucine Lake).

properties.name: Latium Vetus (region)
properties.description: Latium Vetus is an historical region of Italy. Latium Vetus begins south of the Tiber river and extends as far as Circeo, at which point the boundary of Latium Adiectum is reached.

properties.name: Laurentes
properties.description: Laurentum was an ancient city of Latium located some 16 miles from Rome, between Ostia and Lavinium. Its precise location can no longer be determined. In Rome's legendary history Laurentum is the site of king Latinus' dwelling.

properties.name: Magliana Vecchia
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 43 B2 Magliana Vecchia

properties.name: Marmenia
properties.description: The Domus Marmeniae is a villa located on the Via Appia near the fourth milestone. The villa grounds hosted a pagan necropolis and tradition holds that the matrona, Marmenia, relocated the body of St. Urban to a mausoleum built on the grounds.

properties.name: Pons Mulvius
properties.description: Pons Mulvius (the Milvian Bridge) is a Roman bridge over the Tiber river. The original phase of the bridge dates to the consulship of Gaius Claudius Nero in 206 B.C. The bridge is most famous as the site of a decisive battle between Maxentius and Constantine I fought in A.D. 312.

properties.name: Portus
properties.description: The great ancient maritime port of Rome, located on the right-hand bank of the Tiber river.

properties.name: Quintilii
properties.description: A suburban villa built by Sextus Quintilius Maximus and Sextus Quintilius Condianus (consuls in A.D. 151).

properties.name: Regillus? L.
properties.description: An ancient lake in Latium that was the site of a Roman military victory in 496 BC; the precise location of the lake cannot be determined, although some scholars place its location at Pantano Secco near Frascati, Italy.

properties.name: Sabina
properties.description: The one-time territory of the ancient Sabine people of central Italy.

properties.name: Salinae
properties.description: Salt pans located to the east of Ostia and to the north-east of Portus around the Tiber river estuary.

properties.name: S. Alessandro
properties.description: The basilica and catacombs of S. Alessandro are located at the seventh milestone of the Via Nomentana.

properties.name: S. Sebastianus
properties.description: S. Sebastianus (San Sebastiano fuori le mura) is a Christian basilica outside the walls of Rome; the earliest phase belongs to the fourth century AD.

properties.name: Mausoleum of Caecilia Metella
properties.description: A tomb on the Via Appia south of Rome belonging to Caecilia Metella, a daughter of Metellus Creticus. She was born ca. 100 BC. In 1303 the tomb was incorporated into the Castrum Caetani, serving as the main tower of the fortification.

properties.name: Settecamini
properties.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 43 C2 Settecamini

properties.name: Tiberis (river)
properties.description: The Tiber river is the third-longest river of the Italian peninsula, flowing 406 km (252 mi) from the Apennine Mountains to the Tyrrhenian Sea.

properties.name: Tor Marancia
properties.description: The modern toponym Tor Marancia is claimed to derive from the Praedium Amaranthianus, a villa belonging to the second-century A.D. freedman Amaranthus.

properties.name: Torraccia dellu2019Inviolata
properties.description: A Roman tomb, known as the Torraccia dellu2019Inviolata. This tomb has a cruciform plan that is inscribed within a circular structure. Based on masonry techniques the tomb dates to the later first or second century.

properties.name: Il Torraccio
properties.description: The so-called Il Torraccio (1) is the cement core of a Roman tomb located at the twelfth milestone of the Via Appia Nuova, on the left side.

properties.name: Torre di Palidoro
properties.description: A coastal Roman villa that is succeeded by a Medieval coastal tower.

properties.name: Trerus/Tolerus (river)
properties.description: A river of central Italy and a right tributary of the Liris.

properties.name: Tchogha Zanbil
properties.description: An ancient Elamite complex founded ca. 1250 BC by the king Untash-Napirisha. Tchogha Zanbil was added to the UNESCO World Heritage List in 1979.

properties.name: Monjukli Depe
properties.description: Village in southern Turkmenistan located near the Altyn Depe site, inhabited in the late Neolithic and Aeneolithic periods. The finds at the site have been dated from 6200-4350 BCE, with a hiatus in settlement from 5600-4800 BCE.

properties.name: Libraries' Courtyard at Hadrian's Villa
properties.description: The Libraries' Courtyard belongs to the republican period and is one of the most ancient gardens at Hadrian's Villa. It is enclosed in a large peristyle 48 m wide, 72 m long, and is located at the northern end of Villa Adriana.

properties.name: Ionian League
properties.description: An Ancient Greek confederation originally formed in the sixth century BCE by twelve Ionian cities, with religious festivals celebrated at Panionia.

properties.name: Tell Mohammad Diyab
properties.description: An archaeological site in northeastern Syria inhabited in the Early Dynastic through post-Akkadian period (ca. 2750-1800 BCE).

properties.name: Wadi al-Jarf
properties.description: Site on the Red Sea Coast in Egypt, used in the Fourth Dynasty as a port for importing turquoise and copper from Sinai. The oldest surviving papyrus from Egypt, dated during the reign of Khufu (26th century BCE), was found at the site.

properties.name: Byrsa
properties.description: Walled citadel in Carthage built in the early first millennium BCE. The site was destroyed during the Third Punic War in 146 BCE by the forces of Scipio Aemilianus. The hill became the site of the city's forum in the Roman period.

properties.name: Macellum of Sagalassos
properties.description: The Roman Macellum of Sagalassos.

properties.name: Lyceum
properties.description: The seat of Aristotle's Peripatetic school of philosophy at Athens founded in 335/4 B.C. The Lyceum was destroyed by Sulla in 86 B.C.

properties.name: Walls of Caerwent (Venta Silurum)
properties.description: The city walls of Venta Silurum (modern Caerwent) are among the best-preserved Roman period city walls in Britain. The walls were constructed around the 3rd century CE, augmenting an earlier earthwork defense system, with external towers added in the mid 4th century.

properties.name: Ashur/u2018Lambanu2019?/u2018Liba(nai)u2019?
properties.description: Au0161u0161ur, modern Qal'at Sherqat, is an Assyrian city on the western bank of the Tigris River. Named after its enigmatic tutelary deity, it was the original capital, ancestral home, and burial place of the Assyrian royal family. From the late third millennium B.C. until 614 B.C., when the city was captured and destroyed by the Medes, Au0161u0161ur was Assyria's most important religious center. It was also Assyria's principal administrative center until the beginning of the ninth century, when Ashurnasirpal II (883-859) moved the capital to the newly constructed Calah.

properties.name: Babylon

properties.name: Cutha
properties.description: Kutha or Cutha (modern Tell Ibrahim) is located on the Upper Euphrates, north of Nippur and northeast of Babylon. The archaeological site consists of two tells. Archaeological evidence of the Neo-Babylonian period has been revealed by excavation.

properties.name: Nimrud
properties.description: In the ninth century BC, Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883-859 BC) built himself a new administrative center. Kalhu (biblical Calah) u2014 modern Nimrud, a site identified as Larissa, a city mentioned in Xenophonu2019s Anabasis u2014 became the capital of the Assyrian Empire, replacing Ashur, which had served as Assyriau2019s capital since the third millennium BC. The city u2014 which is located twenty miles south of the modern Mosul and which occupied a strategic position six miles north of the point where the Tigris River meets the Greater/Upper Zab u2014 served as Assyriau2019s capital until the reign of Sargon II (r. 721u2013705 BC). Although Kalhu never again became the primary residence of Assyriau2019s kings, that city remained a vital administrative, military, and religious center until the fall of the Assyrian Empire.

properties.name: Samshvilde
properties.description: Fortified settlement in southern Georgia. The Samshvilde site is one of the oldest cities in Georgia, with remains from the Bronze Age Kura-Araxes Culture. Samshvilde was an important city in the late antique and medieval periods until it was sacked in 1440 by Jahan Shah; it went in decline but was inhabited as late as the 18th-19th centuries. The site includes a number of structures, including an 11th-13th century citadel, several early medieval churches, homes, and burial grounds.

This site, whose ancient name and tutelary deities are not known, was extensively excavated in the 1960s. It comprised religious and performative spaces, as well as baths and hostelry.

properties.name: Zabala
properties.description: This Sumerian/Babylonian city (also known as Zabalam, now as modern Tell Ibzeikh) was a cult centre of the goddess Inanna/Ishtar. It was located near the Iturungal and Ninagina canals.

properties.name: Caer Gai
properties.description: The site of a Roman fort in Wales occupied during the late first and early second centuries A.D.

properties.name: San Demetrio ne' Vestini
properties.description: A settlement that was an important center of the Vestini in the Abruzzo.

properties.name: Maa
properties.description: A fortified settlement on Cyprus dating to the thirteenth and twelfth centuries B.C.

properties.name: Basilica of Sant'Apollinare in Classe
properties.description: A basilica begun in the sixth century AD by Bishop Ursicinus with financial support from the Greek banker Iulianus Argentarius.

properties.name: tribus Lemonia
properties.description: An older rural tribe of ancient Rome.

properties.name: Urartu
properties.description: An eastern Anatolian kingdom on the eastern shore of Lake Van. Originating from a regional collection of principalities first mentioned in the 13th century BCE, it had become a single political entity by the 9th century BCE. Urartu was a powerful rival to the Neo-Assyrian Empire. It ceased to exist sometime in the late 7th or early 6th century BCE.

properties.name: Lepti Minus Roman amphitheater
properties.description: The Roman amphitheater of Lepti Minus.

properties.name: Magidu00fb
properties.description: Magidu00fb or Megiddo (modern Tell al-Mutesellim, The Tell of the Governor) is an ancient settlement mound located in northern Israel near Kibbutz Megiddo, about 30 km southeast of Haifa. Bronze Age Megiddo was an important Canaanite city-state and during the Iron Age, it was a royal city in the Kingdom of Israel. The site is mentioned in Neo-Assyrian sources.

properties.name: Porticus Pompei
properties.description: A porticus built in 55 B.C. in connection with the Theater of Pompey. The Curia Pompei, site of Iulius Caesar's assassination in 44 B.C., was likely located within the portico.

properties.name: Arrone (river)
properties.description: The Arrone flows from Lake Bracciano to the Tyrrhenian Sea.

properties.name: Etruscan altar of Grotta Porcina
properties.description: A rock-cut altar dating to the first half of the sixth century B.C.

properties.name: Greta Bridge
properties.description: A Roman fort and associated vicus at modern Greta Bridge (UK).

properties.name: Barbury Castle
properties.description: Barbury Castle is an Iron Age hill fort in Wiltshire, England.

properties.name: Forum Boarium (at Rome)
properties.description: Rome's so-called cattle market, the Forum Boarium is a key area of commercial and ritual activity on the east bank of the river Tiber. It is flanked by the Capitoline, Palatine, and Aventine hills.

properties.name: Ara Maxima Herculis
properties.description: An early cult center connected with Herakles located in Rome's Forum Boarium.

properties.name: Aedes Herculis Pompeiani
properties.description: A temple of Hercules located near the Circus Maximus.

properties.name: Shara Temple at Umma
properties.description: Large temple at Tell Jokha/Umma dedicated to the Sumerian god Shara. The temple was constructed by king u0160u-Suen of the Third Dynasty of Ur (2035-2027 BCE), and was used during the Ur III-Old Babylonian periods.
